Counterblow Hammers

What is a Counterblow Hammer?

Counter blow hammers are majorly used for forming large and ultra large forgings. The counterblow hammer is another variation of the power-drop hammer, which is widely used in Europe. The major advantage of counter blow hammers is that they operate at very high speeds but with less vibration transmitted to the foundation. These hammers develop striking force by the movement of two rams which are simultaneously approaching from opposite directions and meeting at a midway point. Some hammers are pneumatically or hydraulically actuated while others incorporate a mechanical hydraulic or a mechanical pneumatic system.

Construction and Working of a Counterblow Hammer

The basic components of a counter blow hammer are: Drive (hydraulic, pneumatic etc.), Upper Ram, Upper die, Hammer frame, Lower die, Lower ram and Hydraulic ram clutch. In a vertical counter blow hammer with a steam-hydraulic actuating system, steam is admitted to the upper cylinder and drives the upper ram downward. At the same time, pistons connected to the upper ram act through a hydraulic linkage in forcing the lower ram upward. Retraction speed is increased by steam (or air) pressure acting upward on the piston. Through proper design relative to weights (including tooling and work piece) and hydraulics (slower lower-assembly velocities), the kinetic energy of the upper and lower assemblies can be balanced at the impact. Horizontal counter blow hammers have two opposing, die-carrying rams that are moved horizontally by compressed air. Heated stock is positioned automatically at each die impression by a preset pattern of accurately timed movements of a stock handling device. A 90° rotation of stock can be programmed between the blows.

Counterblow Hammer and its Advantages

The rams of a counter blow hammer are capable of striking repeated blows and they develop combined velocities of 5 to 6 m/s (6 to 20 ft/s). Compared to single action hammers, the vibration of impact is reduced, and approximately the full energy of each blow is delivered to the work piece, without loss to an anvil. As a result, the wear of moving hammer parts is minimized, contributing to longer operating life of the machine. At the time of impact, forces are cancelled out, and hence no energy is lost to the foundation. In fact, counterblow hammers do not require the large inertia blocks and foundations needed for conventional power drop hammers which involve comparatively high intense vibrations.

A forge hammer is any hammer or hitting implement that is used during the metal forging process, in order to give shape and to beat out inconsistencies from the metal. As such, there are many types of forging hammers, ranging from the old-fashioned hammer and anvil to the air forging hammer and the drop forge hammer, which are more commonly used in today’s metalworking environment.

Mechanical Forge Hammers

With a traditional hammer and anvil, which relied on the brute strength of the operator, work is slow going, and output is restricted to the items that a single person can create. However, mechanical and eventually hydraulic forging hammer variants were developed, and these replaced muscular power with mechanical and hydraulic power. The modern hammer forging machine can work with a cold or hot forge, and there are different models of used forging hammer available for purchase.

Drop Forge Hammer

The drop forge hammer relies solely on gravity to beat the metal. A column, with foot, is usually dropped inside a cylindrical metal tube, and the item to be pressed or beaten is placed at the foot of the column.

Air Forge Hammers

However, for faster project completion, for the application of more precise amounts of pressure, or when there is a considerable ongoing need for the process to be run, hydraulic and air forging hammer models are usually chosen. These provide greater strength, and the exact amount of pressure can usually be determined by the operator. This has become the more commonly found variant of forging hammer for sale in today’s market.

Planing vs. Shaping

Like shaping machines, planing machines are also basically used for producing flat surfaces in various planes. As in shaping machines, during the planing process as well the length and position of the stroke can be adjusted and only single point cutting tools are used for material removal. Both shaping and planing machines can also be exploited to produce large curved surfaces by employing suitable attachments. For machining grooves in curved sections, form tools are utilized in both the machines. Also most importantly both the machining processes work based on the same cutting principle. Even though there are striking similarities between the two processes, there are a few notable differences between the two of them. In planing machine, instead of the tool, the work piece is given a reciprocatory action thereby responsible for the fast cutting motion and instead of the job, the tool is given the slow feed motion while in shaping machines, it is vice versa. When compared to shaping machines, planer machines are much larger and more rugged in construction and are generally used for machining large jobs with longer stroke length and heavy cuts. A metal power planer machine is also more productive than a shaping machine.

Cutting Mechanism

The planing machine has a relatively simpler kinematic system which enables the transmission and transformation of rotary motion of the main motor into reciprocating motion of the large work table and the slow transverse feed motions (both horizontal and vertical) of the tools. The reciprocation of the table, which imparts cutting motion to the job, is attained by the rack and pinion mechanism. The rack is fitted with the table at its bottom surface and the pinion is fitted on the output shaft of the speed gear box. This kind of arrangement not only enables to change the number of stroke per minute but is also responsible for the quick return of the table thus reducing the time taken for the return stroke. The tool head which holds the cutting tools can be moved horizontally along the cross rail by screw nut system and the cross rail is supported by the column of the machine. Just like the ones used in turning process, the cutting tool used for material removal is a single point cutting tool. The only difference is that the cutting tool for planing must be more rigid as the tool is not subjected to any kind of reciprocatory motion and just feed motion. Also higher tool rigidity is required to withstand the higher impact cutting forces. The clearance angle of the tool also must be bigger to avoid plunging of the cutting tool into the machined surface during the quick return of the ram over the work piece.

Types of Metal Planers

Planing machines can be classified into two types as open side planers and double-column planers. The open side planer, also called as the single column planer has a single column supporting the cross rail on which the tool head is mounted. Width of the parts that can be machined in a single column planer is larger owing to the configuration of the machine. A double column planer has two columns, one on either side of the bed and the worktable. Just like in an open side planer, the columns support the cross rail on which one or more tool heads are mounted. Rigidity and robustness of the double column planers is quite high when compared to open type planers because of the presence of two columns but it has a limitation in the width of the work piece that can be handled in the planer machine.

Application and Advantages of Planers

All the operations that can be done in shaping machines can be performed in a planing machine as well. But larger size and stroke length and higher rigidity enable the planing machines to do more heavy duty work on large jobs and long surfaces. The productivity of the planing machines is also far superior when compared to shaping machines for longer and faster stroke, heavy cuts. There is also possibility of simultaneously using a number of tools in a electric planer which further enhances the production capacity of the planing machine leading to a great amount of reduction in lead time. The most common application of planers is the machining of salient features like the principal surfaces and guide ways of beds and tables of various universally used industrial machines like lathes, milling machines, grinding machines, broaching machines, shapers and planing machines itself etc. Besides this the planers are also utilized for machining long parallel T slots, ‘V’ and inverted ‘V’ type guide ways. The power planers are also employed for few critical machining activities like helical grooving on large rods, long and wide two dimensional curved surfaces and making repetitive oil grooves etc. with the help of suitable special attachments.

A broach machine is used for cutting a range of shapes not possible with other machines. Any broaching machine for sale will be designed to move a broach - a toothed tool - linearly in cutting unusual shapes such as keyways. The broach will cut either horizontally or vertically with a vertical broaching machine. The majority of broaching operations are powered by hydraulic broaching machine setups.

Broaching Machine Setup

The tool a horizontal broaching machine uses is much like a saw and removes material in the same way. A machine of this type will have a relatively simple setup where the tool is pushed against the work piece hydraulically in a vertical or horizontal motion. Horizontal machines are used for longer cutting operations.

The Range of Options

A vertical broaching machine is the most common type used today, with an estimated 10% of broaching jobs completed on a horizontal broaching machine. The types of broaching machine will indicate the broaching possibilities. Horizontal machines are often used for surface, pull, rotary and continuous broaching while vertical options may be used for pull-down operations.

Uses of Broaching Machines

A broach machine specialises in precision machining for the cutting of unusual or odd geometries such as splines. Common products manufactured from a broaching process include screws, castings and stampings. Broaching is used for production processes when a high quantity of product is required.

Honing is a low velocity finishing process performed by a specific tool called as the honing tool which contains a set of bonded abrasive sticks or stones. A common application of honing process is to finish the internal cylindrical surface. It also improves the form tolerance of the holes. Honing uses bonded abrasives just as in grinding while loosened abrasives are used in lapping & polishing. The point of contact during honing is not just a line as in grinding instead a complete area of the tool. In addition to the surface finish of about 0.1 µm, honing produces a characteristic crosshatched surface that tends to retain lubrication during operation of the component, thus contributing to its function and service life.

Honing Tool

The honing tool performs a combined rotary and reciprocating motion while the work piece does not perform any working motion. The point behind providing rotational and reciprocating movements is to give an uneven ratio and thus prevent an abrasive grain from ever traversing its own path twice. Also this type of a complex rotational and oscillatory axial motion of the hone is responsible for the crosshatched lay pattern of very low surface roughness. The abrasive sticks or stones are equally spaced about the periphery of the hone tool. The abrasives are held against the work surface with controlled light pressure usually exercised by small springs. The abrasive action of the honing tool removes material from the inside diameter of the part. A cutting fluid (honing oil) must be used in honing to cool and lubricate the tool and to help remove the chips. It also prevents pickup (spot welding of tool to bore) and loading (chips coating the stone).

Selection of Abrasives

For a required surface finish and material removal rate, the abrasive stones should be selected based on the flowing parameters: Type of abrasive, Grit size and Hardness. The four types of abrasives used are: Aluminium oxide, Silicon carbide, Cubic Boron Nitride (CBN) and Diamond. Among these, Aluminium oxide is the most commonly used abrasive in industrial applications. CBN and Diamond are used for very hard materials and are called super abrasives. Coarse grains are used for faster stock removal and fine grains are used when less material removal rate and fine finish are required. Coarse grains are used for ductile materials and fine grains are used for hard and brittle materials.

Types of Honing Machines: Vertical and Horizontal

There are two types of honing machines:

  • Vertical Honing Machine
  • Horizontal Honing Machine

Vertical honing machines hold the work piece and the honing tool with their axes in the vertical position while in horizontal honing machines both the work as well as the tool are held with their axes in horizontal direction. Vertical machines are suited for shorter jobs while horizontal machines are preferred for longer jobs. Part lengths up to 2000 mm are usually honed in vertical machines and jobs of more than 2000 mm length are honed in horizontal machines.

On TradeMachines, you have the possibility to find a wide choice of honing machines for sale, including sunnen honing machine, cylinder honing machine, portable honing machine, CNC honing machine, engine honing machine, etc.

Advantages and Disadvantages of Honing

The honing process offers advantages of low capital equipment cost, high metal removal rates, and extreme accuracy of 0.001mm in a wide variety of materials. It gives relatively high productivity when compared to a lapping machine. Several holes can be honed simultaneously on multiple spindle machines. Other advantages include the ability to create round and straight bores in relatively long work pieces, freedom from heat effects etc. It avoids surface damage due to heat as can occur with grinding operations. As there is no motion involved with the work piece, there are no chucks, faceplates, or rotating tables needed thereby eliminating chances of chucking or locating errors. The hone is driven from a central shaft, so bending of the shaft cannot cause tapered holes as it does when boring. The resultant crosshatch pattern of honing is very efficient in a moving bearing application such as an automotive cylinder bore honing tool or a valve body bore, since the peaks carry the load of the mating part and the valleys in the surface structure provides reservoirs for lubricating oil.

Honing machine process can be used to correct the following bore errors generated during the previous operations:

  • Curvature
  • Conicity
  • Taper
  • Waviness
  • Undersize
  • Lack of Roundness

Honing equipment can also correct parts that are not square, within limits. But the major constraint is that the part must have convenient clamping pads as work piece distortion during application of the process will not be caused. As the honing tool also gets worn out quickly, it should be sharpened from time to time for maintaining the quality of the products. Also the initial equipment cost is quite high when compared to other finishing processes. Hence, it is advisable to go for used honing machines for sale when cost restriction plays an important role.

A slotter or slotting machine is basically a heavy duty shaping machine in which the cutting tool moves vertically. The ram is mounted on an independent bearing, the upper part of which is pivoted to shift the ram in any angular position. The job is generally supported on a round table that has a rotary feed in addition to the usual table movements in cross-directions. Thus the work table can be given transverse, longitudinal or rotary movement. A slotting machine works on the same principle as an ordinary shaper except that the ram which carries the tool moves in the vertical direction at right angles to the work piece. Slotters are commonly used for internal machining of blind holes, key ways, recesses and also for the cutting of internal and external teeth on large gears.

Shaping vs. Slotting

The chief difference between a shaper and a slotter is the direction of the cutting action. The cutting tool moves vertically up and down while performing the cutting operation as against the horizontal to and fro motion in a shaper. Also the depth of cut is adjusted by moving the cutting tool horizontally in a slotter machine whereas vertical movement of the tool in a shaper is responsible for determining the depth of cut. Slotting machines are characterized by longer stroke length than shaping machines. They are also less strong and rigid comparatively. And slotting machines are used mostly for machining internal surfaces while shapers are predominantly used for machining flat surfaces.

Specification of a Slotter

Slotters are generally specified in terms of the maximum length of a stroke. A little consideration will show that the size of the job that can be machined will be less than this size by an amount equal to the top and bottom clearances of the tool. The ram stroke of a slotter for sale ranges from 300 to 1800 mm. Longitudinal & transverse feeds range from 0.05 to 2.5 mm/stroke. There is also a possibility of tilting the ram up to 15 degrees on both the sides from vertical permitting the machining of dies with relief. Ram speeds usually vary from 2 to 40m/min. The other common specifications of a slotting machine are: Work table diameter (mm), Transverse movement of the table (mm), Longitudinal movement of the table (mm), Motor Power (KW), Maximum distance between tool post to bed (mm) and Maximum distance between ram guide and work table (mm).

Slotting Drive

In a slotting machine, the cutting action is performed during downward stroke. The mechanism of slotter should be designed in such a way that the ram should move slowly during the cutting stroke and should move fast during the return stroke, thereby the idle time of the machine is reduced. This mechanism is known as Quick return Mechanism. This can be achieved by three means:

  • Crank & Slotted Link - Slotted disc mechanism
  • Driving wheels & Trunnion - Slotted link and gear mechanism
  • Hydraulic Power - Hydraulic mechanism

Cutting speed depends on Stroke length, Number of strokes and Quick return ratio which is the ratio of the duration of forward stroke to the return stroke. Quick return ratio usually varies between 2:1 and the practical limit is 3:2. Some of the advantages of a hydraulically powered slotter over the other mechanisms are:

  1. Greater flexibility of speed
  2. Smoother in operation
  3. Ability to slip in case of overload, thereby eliminating tool and machine damage
  4. Possibility of changing speeds and feeds during operation
  5. Providing a constant speed all over the stroke.

Types of Slotters

The slotting machines can fall into any of the following three types:

  • Puncher Slotter
  • Production Slotter
  • Tool room Slotter

The puncher slotters are heavy duty machines equipped with powerful motor. As the length of the stroke is very large in these kind of slotter machines, they are commonly used for removing large amount of material from large castings or forgings. Production slotters are used for general production work which does not involve greater precision & accuracy. The third type of slotting machine is lighter and operable at higher speeds. It is of the precision type and used for very accurate machining. If you are looking for a used slotting machine for sale, you can easily find these different types of slotters on TradeMachines,

Application of Slotters

The usual and possible machining applications of slotting machines and slotting machines tools are:

  • Internal flat surfaces
  • Enlargement and finishing of non-circular holes bounded by a number of flat surfaces
  • Blind geometrical holes like hexagonal socket
  • Internal grooves and slots of rectangular and curved sections.
  • Internal keyways and splines, straight tooth of internal spur gears, internal curved surface of circular section, internal oil grooves etc. which are not possible in shaping machines.

Productivity and process capability of slotting machines are very poor and hence employed mostly for piece production involving maintenance and repair work in small industries. But, slotters are also used in high volume operations like steel rolling mills, paper mills, power plants, ship building, textile factories, tool rooms, and repair shops.

Pipe Bending Machines

Tube or Pipe bender machines are available for pipes of all sizes from those used in ball point pens up to those for big pipelines. There are two different types of machines available that can process tubes of almost all diameters and wall thicknesses. Tube bending machines with a single clamp, clamp the pipe in on one side and then bend it into the defined profile. The tube is nestled along the whole area concerned and then only released when the desired radius is reached. This process works at a very high level of precision and can produce consistent quality, even for mass produced bent tubes.

The second type of basic structure of a pipe bending machine is the machine made out of three movable rollers. These rollers can be switched out to exactly fit the diameter of the tube. The rollers are positioned in an equilateral triangle. The tube is then placed into the machine and the middle roller is hydraulically driven in between the other two rollers. The distance between the two static rollers and the length of travel of the moveable roller depends on the radius of the curvature of the tube. This process is particularly suited for individual pieces, custom made products or assembly work on construction sites.

The Range of Pipe Bending Machines

Pneumatically operated tube bending machines are used to mass produce cannulas and small tubes of a similar size. The tube bending machines, which operate using a lever and muscle power, are most often used in workshops. Operating these tools requires some experience and one can quickly learn how to produce good results. The manufacturing or adjustment of exhaust pipes for automobiles can be offered very cheaply when produced using this method. There are even hand operated pipe bending machines available for stronger or particularly hard materials like stainless steel, which are partly hydraulically operated. Similar to hydraulically operated jacks, these machines bend the tube using a pressure cylinder and a radius profile. More powerful CNC controlled pipe bending machines are used for industrial settings. These undertake the whole forming process in one stage. Particularly high-end workstations of this kind also offer laser processing. Using this feature, one machine can produce a complex and high-end component for special application within a series.

Lapping is regarded as the oldest process of obtaining fine finish. Lapping process can be defined as a cutting process with loose abrasive grains dispersed in a paste, which is guided on the lapping tool with non-directional paths. Lapping produces smooth, flat, dimensionally accurate surfaces. The major difference between lapping operation and other finishing processes like Grinding & Honing is the usage of loosened abrasive particles instead of bonded abrasives as cutting edges. Also a high-quality surface finish of up to 0.1 µm and a very tight tolerance, as small as ±0.00005 mm is achieved in lapping compared to the ±0.0025 mm achieved during grinding.

Lapping can be performed manually by hand as well as by machines but lapping machines accomplish the process with greater consistency and efficiency. Also hand lapping is rarely used as it is expensive and requires high level of skill. The major parts of a lapping machine are: lapping plate, lapping table, abrasives and the lapping fluid or the vehicle. In lapping, two surfaces are rubbed together with a lapping medium (lapping fluid and lapping grit) trapped between them. Material is removed by countless loose particles between the carrier surface (lapping plate) and the work piece pressed against it.

Lapping Plates and Abrasives

Lapping plates, or simply laps, can be classified into four categories:

  • Soft working plates (Paper, Cloth, Wood)
  • Hard working plates (Cast iron, Steel, Soft ceramics)
  • Hardened working plates (Hardened cast iron, Hardened steel, Hard ceramics)
  • Multi-metal plates (Combination of 2-3 metals)

Abrasive particles in the form of loose grains are suspended in a fluid thereby forming a slurry. Oil is the most preferred vehicle which carries the abrasive grains. Grease are also used at times. The fluid should be chosen in such a way that when large abrasive grains are used, a thick film should be selected and similarly small grains are suspended in thin films. And abrasives belong to the following four categories: Aluminium oxide, Silicon carbide, Cubic Boron Nitride (CBN) and Diamond. Abrasive grit must be uniformly graded to be effective in lapping. Soft materials are lapped with Aluminium oxide and hard materials are lapped with Silicon carbide or Diamond. Particle size, distribution, hardness, shape and number of edges are the quality criteria to be considered. The particle size is chosen according to the necessary rate of material removal and surface finish required.

Working with a Lapping Machine

Lapping machines, such as valve lapping machine, back lapping machine, flat lapping machine, double sided lapping machine, center lapping machine or benchtop lapping machine, are fairly simple pieces of equipment consisting of a rotating table, the lapping plate, and three or four conditioning rings. Standard machines have lapping plates from 12 in. to 48 in. in diameter. The lapping plate is most frequently made of high-quality soft cast iron, though some are made of copper or other soft metals. The work is held in the conditioning rings which rotate. The rotation of the conditional rings plate distributes the wear so that the lapping plate stays flat for a longer time. Secondly it holds the work piece in place. The speed at which the plate turns is determined by the job being done. In doing very critical parts, 10 to 15 rpm is used. Work pieces must be pressurized by about 3 pounds per square inch (psi). Sometimes their own weight is sufficient. If not, a round, heavy pressure plate is placed in the conditioning ring. Also parts to be lapped should be placed securely in the condition rings, otherwise movement among them may lead to damages on the edges. Lapping time depends on the amount of stock to be removed, the abrasive used and the quality required.

Advantages and Disadvantages of Lapping Machines & Lapping Tools

Lapping procedure can be performed on any type of material and of any shape as long it is flat. Any type of material from diamond to plastics can be lapped. The type of material only affects the rate of material removal and the surface quality obtained. And as the parts are not clamped and no heat generation is involved, there is no warping which is a major advantage. Even though it is a material removal process, there are no burrs produced instead it removes those left in the primary processes. The major limitation of lapping machining is that it can be performed only on flat surfaces. Parts having very complex geometries cannot be lapped. Lapping is an art as a lot of process variables are involved and therefore highly experienced operators with sufficient skills can only handle the machines. Proper training and education should be imparted to the operators before working on the machine.

Dowel Driving Machines

Dowel Pins and Insertion

Dowel pins also termed as parallel pins, are solid metal cylindrical fasteners usually precision ground to close tolerance diameter (to permit accurate fitting) that are used for a wide range of industrial applications and it is found in many of the products which we use in our day to day life like chairs, toys, doors etc. They are used to firmly retain parts in a fixed position, maintain alignment between different parts and also to join different components together.Dowel pins are normally made of stainless steel, alloy steel or hardened steel. Dowel driving machines, popularly known as dowel driving machines as the name suggests are used primarily to locate dowel pins into the dowel holes at specified angles and depth which can be controlled with the help of CNC (Computer numerical Control). Dowel driving machines are primarily used in wood working industries especially in the production of doors and windows.

Dowel pins are held in place by interference created around the entire pin circumference when it is pressed into a hole by a dowel driving machine. However, some applications for solid pins require clearance or transition fits on at least one of the components to be fastened. When a dowel is interference fitted into a blind hole, it increases the pressure of the air trapped in the hole. Therefore it is strongly advised to specify that the dowel should have an air release flat ground along its full length to prevent the dowel being ejected under the pressure of compressed air, or bursting the component into which it is driven. The dowel joint assembly is just like a regular screw joint except that dowel pins are used instead of screws.

Working of Dowel Inserters

Hole piercing or drilling and positioning of dowels is extremely important for accurate insertion of dowels. Location, angle, depth and the material of construction are the factors to be considered. Dowel driving process may either include drilling of holes or a standalone dowel driving mechanism. The dowel driving machine may be as simple as dowel insertion guns or highly complex machines capable of inserting several dowel pins simultaneously. A small amount of glue into each hole in one board and the dowels are inserted into the glued holes. There should be specific control on the amount of glue applied as too much of glue will either squeeze out or make it difficult to insert the dowels. Any squeezed out glue should be immediately cleaned up. The refilling of the dowels takes place in a chute batch by batch. For precise adherence of the drilling gap to the leading edge of the work piece, a work piece stopper powered by a linear motor is used. As soon as the operator presses a switch or peddle, the machine will drive the dowel pins into the respective holes. As accurate positioning of the dowels is highly important prior to insertion, the measurement system required for positioning is directly integrated into the motor and high precision measurement systems are usually used. The drilling units if already integrated in the machine are positioned and synchronized also with the same drive.

A dowel driving machine is arranged in such a way that a single head is provided with a single shaft hole and multiple receiving holes, for independently receiving different kinds of dowels, arranged side by side in parallel. The selection is made out of the different kinds of dowel pins with different diameters and lengths supplied from chutes to the respective receiving holes. As a result, different kinds of dowels can be driven easily without much of setup time spent in changing the machine arrangement hence making the machine more suitable for integration into a continuous production line and mass production system. The dowel driving machine consists of a common base or bench and the part where the dowel should be pinned is held firmly with the help of multiple arms. Pinning of the dowels is sensor controlled for position and depth. Most of the semi-automatic dowel driving machines is pneumatic controlled.

Advanced Dowel Driving Machines

The dowel insertion machines range from manually driven dowel insertion gun to medium sized dowel insertion jig. Also fully automated machines are also available in the market. A highly sophisticated dowel driving machine has a cycle lead time of merely five seconds for drilling, gluing and inserting pins into the holes. It is a closed loop system with a self-diagnostic programmer to control all the machine function. In advanced machines, there are multiple spindles for the drilling and inserting operation thereby multiple jobs could be carried out at the same time and the holes of varied dimensions could be also controlled based on the range of operability. Most of the semi-automatic machines are pneumatic controlled. Some of the advantages of fully automated dowel driving machines are: continuous supply of dowel pins with constant feed rate, high precision with adjustable working length and width, less labour intensive and low time consumption.

What is a dowel machine?

A dowel in woodworking is a wooden rod, cut into short length. Dowels are often used for joints between two pieces of timber, i.e. in furniture manufacturing for reinforcement. The joint they make is strong since dowels are relatively thick (thicker than nails or screws). 

Dowel machines are used for drilling holes in wood so a dowel can be later applied. Drilling requires extreme accuracy, so the hole matches the dowel perfectly. Later, glue is applied into the hole (the process resembles an injection) and a dowel is inserted into the hole. The whole procedure is easy and fast, takes only a few seconds. Dowel machines are used very often for mass production.

CNC MACHINING CENTERS

HISTORY OF CNC MACHINES 

CNC refers to a computer that is joined to the NC machine to make the machine more versatile. Therefore, it is obvious that CNC came into existence after its predecessor NC (Numerically Controlled) machines, which were hard wired. In the early 1950’s, the first numerically controlled machine was developed by the Parsons to manufacture quickly complex jet aircraft parts for the US Air Material Command. With the availability of microprocessors, the controller technology made a tremendous progress with the support of which, in the years 1970 - 1972 first Computer Numeric Control machines were developed. Punched tape continued to be used as a medium for transferring G-codes into the controller for many decades till the 1960’s, and then it was eventually superseded by RS232 cables, floppy disks, and now it is directly tied into plant networks. Modern CNC machines use software programs to provide the instructions necessary to control various operating parameters hence they are often termed as soft wired numerical control. The introduction of CNC machines drastically changed the manufacturing industry with its ability to machine curves, intricate shapes and complex 3-D structures so easily with the number of machining steps that required human effort radically reduced. 

WHAT ARE CNC MACHINING CENTERS?

In conventional machine tools the motion is caused by turning cranks and handwheels, while in the case of CNC machines almost all the motions are performed through programmed commands. The motion type (rapid, linear, and circular), the axes to move, the amount of motion and the motion rate (feed rate) are programmable with almost all CNC machine tools. The machining center, developed in the late 50’s is a machine tool capable of performing machining operations simultaneously on a work part in one setup under NC program control which was later facilitated by the addition of a computer to monitor and control the entire unit. CNC Milling machines are termed as CNC machining centers and they are often retro fitted with CNC technology and some special features by removing all the mechanisms built into the machine which requires a large amount of human intervention such as hand wheels etc. Nowadays there are many milling machines which are built specifically for CNC as opposed to being retrofitted at a later stage. Some of these machines are absolutely massive and have built in tool changers, auto-feed mechanisms for loading in material and various electrical sensors for safe monitored cutting.

CLASSIFICATION OF CNC MACHINING CENTERS 

Machining centers can be classified as vertical, horizontal, or universal based upon the orientation of the machine spindle: A vertical machining center has its spindle on a vertical axis relative to the work table. A vertical machining center (VMC) is typically used for flat work pieces that require tool access from the top. E.g. mould and die cavities, large components of aircraft A horizontal machining center (HMC) is used for cube shaped parts where tool access can be best achieved from the sides of the cube. A universal machining center (UMC) has a work head that swivels its spindle axis to any angle between horizontal and vertical making it a very flexible and versatile machine tool. E.g.: aerofoil shapes, curvilinear geometries. 

FEATURES OF CNC MACHINING CENTERS

machining centers are usually designed in such a way with the following features so that the non-productive time is reduced to the maximum extent which make them the most preferred machines. • Automatic tool changer: The tools are contained in a storage unit that is integrated with the machine tool. When a cutter needs to be changed, the tool drum rotates to the proper position and an automatic tool changer (ATC) operating under program control, exchanges the tool in the spindle for the tool in the tool storage unit. Capacities of tool storage unit commonly range from 16 to 80 cutting tools. • Automatic work part positioner: Many horizontal and vertical machining centers have the capability to orient the work part relative to the spindle. This is accomplished by means of a rotary table on which work part is fixed. The table can be oriented at any angle about a vertical axis to permit the cutting tool to access almost the entire surface of the part in a single setup. • Automatic pallet changer: Machining centers are often equipped with two (or more) separate pallets that can be presented to the cutting tool using an automatic pallet changer. While machining is performed with one pallet in position at the machine, the other pallet is in a safe location away from the spindle. In this location, the operator can unload the finished part and then work on the raw work piece for the next cycle. 

ADVANTAGES AND LIMITATIONS OF CNC 

When compared to the conventional CNC machine tools, the CNC machining centers are advantageous in the following ways: Reduced handling time of the parts Fewer number of steps are involved resulting in increased productivity Increased accuracy and repeatability because the parts utilize the same fixture throughout their processing The CNC machining centers are also affected with the same disadvantages of the conventional CNC machine tools like high amount of initial investment but which can be recovered very soon in the long run during mass production. The machining center should be also be well maintained as they are expensive to repair with high costs accounted for maintenance also. It is also restricted with the basic requirement of skilled CNC programmers. 

APPLICATIONS OF CNC MACHINES 

machines are widely used in the manufacturing industries mainly for the production of following kind of parts: Parts with complicated contours Parts requiring close tolerance and or good repeatability Parts which require complex and expensive jigs and fixtures when produced on conventional machines Parts which are to be manufactured without any room for human errors. Parts which have changing requirements like the ones which are in the development stages. Parts which are required urgently. Small batches or production lots.

Edge Banding Machine

Panel processing machinery is a type of woodworking equipment that is used for dividing sheet materials into the desired sized panels. Edge processing equipment is used to apply a neat, finished edge to the raw cut edge of sheet materials.

Edge Banding Machine And The Leading Manufacturers

Varnishing Machines

What is a Varnish Machine?

Varnishes provide protective coatings for wooden surfaces and various decorative objects. They protect and enhance the appearance of wooden floors and furniture. It is used for protecting wood from straining, abrasion, weather and water penetration. It is also used for giving the glossiness to paper surfaces. Varnishing machine is a product integrating light machinery with pneumatic control. It realizes whole-course automation and adopts belt conveying with high speed and efficiency. Machines are suitable for automatic impregnating of stators and rotors by trickle process. Stators and Rotors are heated to pre-determined temperature and then trickled with varnish and cured until it hardens. It is used to varnish Stators, Rotors, Coils, Transformer stack windings, small electronics transformers, etc.

Construction and Working of Varnishing Machines

The four major parts of a varnishing machine are:

  • STREAM FEEDER – It is a suction head with vacuum pump suction system Capable of being adjusted while running.
  • UV COATING UNIT – It is equipped with high sensitivity wind-knife system and suited for glazing of thick and thin paper
  • UV DRYING UNIT – It’s function is to promote the glossiness of the paper surface. UV radiation makes the UV oil harden and become resistant to wear.
  • AUTOMATIC DELIVERY UNIT – Conveyor belt produces low noise and make delivery smooth with its upper and lower pressing track design. Smearing on thin paper tends to produce curling, but the paper is kept stable with the pneumatic sheet jogging device knocking up both sides of sheet.

Varnish Machine fitted with roller bearings ensure smooth & light running of the machine. The machine is semi-automatic and leaver impression of Varnish only when paper is fed. Conveyor belt stand with special arrangement for adjusting delivery tapes. Gumming is also done with this machine. According to the principle of Impregnation, activated resin is trickled in a thin jet on to the rotating preheated winding. The resin immediately gets heated and its viscosity is reduced. Due to the rotary motion of the winding the resin gets distributed evenly inside the winding without any drain loss. The heated winding accelerates the gelling and curing of the resin.

Application of Varnishing Machines

The machine is used for both flood and spot varnishing on light and thick paper with accurate and even spot coating register. It is suitable for spot or full coating on words and graphics in books, advertisement sheets, colour paperboard to enhance its dimensional quality and surface protection. Integrated control with PLC can provide easy operation & trouble shooting during production. It is a fully automated working process from feeding to delivery.

What does the wood finishing process involve?

Wood finishing process involves all the measures taken to refine or protect a wooden surface. The process is one of the steps required in manufacturing furniture. Thanks to wood finishing it is easier to maintain the wood in a good condition and clean it. Its durability and resistance to moisture is also increased. 

Basic wood finishing procedure involves planning, sanding (removing defects like cutter marks, scratches etc.), bleaching, removing stains and coloring. When all these steps are completed, the finish is applied. The finish consists of several layers (wax, oil, varnish etc.).

What is a Varnish Dryer?

The term varnish is used to designate any solution, which, when spread with a brush in a thin layer on the surface of an object, dries with a smooth, lustrous, transparent film. Varnish has very good resistance against abrasion, wear, heat, solvents and water vapour. Varnish should be dried as quicker as possible after its application as there are chances for more dust to settle in the finish if it has a longer drying time. Varnish dryers are solutions of the metal salts of organic acids dissolved in mineral spirits. They are used in paints and varnishes to help the oils dry. They are sold based on the metal content of the solution, i.e. the cobalt dryer contains 6% cobalt metal. The varnish dryers are cobalt, calcium, manganese, zirconium, etc. Varnish dryer is an additive used to improve drying times. It is ideally used for cool or humid areas, for external projects when rain is expected or for reducing the time of projects which require multiple coats. The linseed oil used in oil varnishes is boiled with the addition of certain so-called dryers, of which red lead and certain compounds of manganese treated in various ways are the most important. The dryer is introduced into the oil, either directly or through the medium of the resins of lead and manganese. Linseed oil gains from 14 to 16% in weight in drying, due to the oxygen it absorbs.

Characteristics of a Good Varnish Dryer

A good dryer should dry twenty parts of oil in 12 to 24 hours at the longest. The dryer should mix readily with the oil, otherwise if it separates and is insoluble, it can be put aside as of little value. The behaviour in drying should also be noted. The film of oil should dry smooth and free from crinkles and or other imperfections. Comparisons between different dryers can be made easily by this method of adding fixed, accurately measured proportions of dryer to raw oil and observing the action of the mixtures side by side. A fluid ounce of liquid contains 480 drops. 24 drops of dryer to the ounce of raw linseed oil would be about 1 part to 20. Varnishes can be tested by spreading them on glass and observing their action in drying and the nature of the surfaces they produce. Exposure to steam and the weather will develop their wearing qualities or lack of them.

The History of Wood Cutting Tools

Saws and saw-like tools are some of the oldest findings to come out of the early Stone Age. Saw blades made out of metal were detected in ancient Egypt. For example, a fine Egyptian woodworking saw with a saw blade made out of copper was found and dated back to 1200 BC.

Using Woodworking Saws

Nowadays to get a used wood cutting machine is something common and normal as it is that users look for the best offers or even auctions. While a smooth blade, a knife can separate material without resulting in chippings or even as wood carving tools . On the other hand, sawing results in a lot of wood chips, which separate from the work piece. The table saw is it generally made on an arbor, driven by an electric motor. The blade protrudes through the surface of a table, which gives support for the material, usually wood, being cut. Thereby, the saw blades creates a kerf, which is at least as wide as the saw blade, if not larger. In order to prevent the saw blade from getting stuck in the work piece, the teeth are normally straight-set. This means that they orient themselves to both sides and alternately face outwards. The saw blades create a similar effect; they are relief ground or curled around the area of the teeth.

Bimetal tools change their form during the heating of a saw blade, so that the kerf is wider. There exist many woodworking machinery auctions where to buy wood cutting machines and used wood cutting tools. There is a limit to the length of a saw blade, which ensures that it doesn't break. This also means that most electric wood saws do not work continuously. The exceptions to this include the circular saw, band saw and chainsaw, which are most commonly used as sawing machine tools in woodworking. Continuously operating sawing tools usually require an idle stroke between the two consecutive working strokes, because saw blades are usually only configured to work in one direction. Wood saws with a double-sided set saw blade are used for severance cuts (e.g. crosscut saws) or for very stiff constructions (e.g. back saws or fine saws). A specific wood cutting equipment is essential to maintain the saw blades and all the woodworking tools.

Used Double Cross Cut Saws

 -What is a Double Cross Cut Saw?

The double blade cross cut saw is a semi-automatic tool for lumber trimming to an exact length. The saw is a continuous workflow workbench where the lumber is moved by a chain conveyer across two ripsaws, which cut off the ends of the lumber. The conveyer speed can be adjusted with a frequency converter. The double blade cross cut saw can be fast and easily set up depending upon the required lumber length. The setting mechanism consists of an electrical drive which moves the ripsaws closer or further apart. The exact position of the timber can be determined by using a ruler attached to the ripsaw adjustment system.

Construction of Double Cross Cut Saw

The double cross cut saw is composed of two beams which are used to hold the cutting blades, the height of which can be lowered as required. These beams are positioned at such a precise angle above the board by using a check algorithm to make sure that the resulting cut is perpendicular to the side of the board. The blade carriages run on compact slides with a special integral ball bearing system driven by a highly resistant toothed belt, by means of pulleys, reducers, and electronically driven brushless motors. 

The cutting blades are equipped with protection guards for the operator’s safety as well as for protecting the surrounding area. The work area can be kept clean by placing four suction points, two of which are mobile and the other two are located underneath the cutting surface of the board. Two pincer rollers, which have a central core with high density polyurethane covered rings, are normally placed just prior to and after the cutting area to ensure a constant board speed. These pincer rollers are driven using an electric axle to make sure that the speed at which the board advances is perfectly synchronized. The electric control of the machine provides numerous possibilities, all of which are fully programmable.

Advantages of Double Cross Cut Saw

The following are some of the advantages of using double cross cut saw machine for sawing down wood: 

  • Exact cutting to size and correct angle 
  • Perfect cutting quality  
  • Minimum setup time and Rational modes of operation 
  • Scratch and trace free surface 
  • Precision throughout entire service-life

Diesel forklifts for sale on TradeMachines

A forklift truck is a flexible handling device designed to facilitate the transport and storage of goods. Forklifts are classified according to their energy (electric, gas or diesel) and lifting capacity. They allow easy and reliable material handling in tight spaces, making them essential equipment for many sectors such as logistics, manufacturing or construction.

A diesel forklift truck is composed of the following elements, each having an importance in the way machine operates:

  • Lifting mast
  • Overheard Guard
  • Cab Enclosure
  • Counterweight
  • Steering wheel
  • Drive wheels and load wheels
  • Chassis
  • Forks
  • Carriage
  • Tilt Cylinder
  • Lift Cylinders
  • Load backrest

How to choose between diesel, electric or LPG forklift trucks?

Diesel fork trucks are large machines capable of lifting from 1.5 to 16 tonnes. They work well in harsh environments, and are suitable for outdoor use. Before choosing a particular model, we recommend you to define what height, type of masts or additional attachments will best meet your needs. The lift cylinder and the side shifts will allow you to adjust the height and inclination of the fork according to the objects to be lifted. Pay attention to these details when searching for forklift trucks on Trade Machines.

Characteristics of a diesel forklift

Diesel forklifts are characterized by their power, ease of maintenance and high robustness. These machines are made to last long. With a longer service life than LPG or electric, and attractive purchase price, many companies opt for these vehicles. With competitive maintenance costs on top of that, you will save a lot on your expenses.

Diesel forklifts offer significant advantages, they do not need to be recharged, can be used even outdoors and are more powerful than LPG or electric forklifts. However, in the long term, diesel consumption can become a problem, which is why many warehouses and logistics platforms are replacing their old energy-intensive equipment with more environmentally friendly one.

Maintenance and use of used diesel forklifts

Diesel-powered forklifts are mainly used outdoors. Their use indoors is prohibited due to emissions from diesel engines, which contain soot and carbon monoxide. Breathing it in may be harmful and lead to poisoning. Therefore, diesel forklifts are equipped with air conditioning, heating, fans etc.  

Although suitable for continuous use, once cooled, diesel forklifts may have difficulties starting due to diesel engines. To avoid this kind of experience, choose a model with a preheating system. Check oil and coolant level regularly to keep your vehicle running well.

What are the main brands of diesel forklift trucks?

The first brand on the forklift truck market was Clark (USA, 1917). However, Toyota is considered to be the top diesel forklift manufacturer (based on sales). Choosing brands that are recognized as key players on the market is a smart move. You can be sure to find spare parts easily or someone who will be capable of maintaining your vehicle.

Do I need a forklift training?

All forklift operators are required to obtain a special OSHA forklift training and certification (OSHA - U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration), when commercial driver’s licence (Class A, B, C, etc.) is not necessary. The forklift certification is valid for 3 years, and after that period you will need a renewal. 

It is extremely important to be well trained and legally certified while operating heavy equipment. The training covers truck-related topics (operating the truck, vehicle capacity, limitations, etc.) and workplace-related topics (surface conditions, pedestrian traffic etc.).

Characteristics of Cranes

Cranes are material handling equipment designed for lifting and moving heavy loads. They are basically used to move loads over variable ( horizontal and vertical) paths within a restricted area. They are preferred over other material handling equipments when there is insufficient or intermittent flow volume, for example when the use of a conveyor cannot be justified in the movement of goods. Cranes are more flexible in the transportation of material than the conveyors but at the same time not as flexible as industrial trucks. Loads handled by these machines are more varied with respect to their shape and weight than those handled by a conveyor. Mostly hoists are utilized by cranes for vertical movement, although manipulators can be used if precise positioning of the load is required

History & Development of Cranes

They have been used since ancient times, the chimney or fireplace cranes were used to turn the pots and kettles on the fire, while the height was governed by a trammel hook. In ancient Greece, the cranes were widely used and it can also be quoted that the construction of these machines probably begun with the ancient Greeks. They played an important role in the construction of tall buildings & temples. During the middle ages, they were introduced for lifting, loading and unloading ships in harbours as well as aid in their construction. It was in harbours where they developed rapidly due to the importance of trade. Later, handling machines were built heavily with the use of tread wheels, which permitted lifting of much greater weights. Nowadays machines employ internal combustion engines or electric motors or hydraulic systems to provide increased capability in lifting weights. Additionally there are the mobile ones which are mounted on trucks. When the provision of power is a major concern, manual cranes come into the picture. Today these are used extensively within the construction industry with a host of different varieties from tower to mobile cranes.

Types of Cranes

Though there are many classifications based on the purpose of use, the three main types used in industrial environments are:

  • Bridge Cranes
  • Gantry Cranes
  • Jib Cranes

Bridge Cranes : It consists of one or two horizontal beams supported between fixed rails on either end. The hoist moves along the length of the bridge, and the bridge moves along the rails. The x- and y-axes movements are provided by the above said movement and the hoist provides motion in the z-axis direction. In the bridge crane, vertical lifting is due to the hoist and horizontal movement of the material is due to the rail system. They are used in heavy machinery fabrication, steel mills, and power-generating stations. The major advantage of this handling machine is that it enables three dimensional handling with ease & precision. Top riding and underhung are the two versions . Top riding is used for lifting heavier loads but the underhung cranes are the most versatile ones as they can also interface with other material handling systems.

Gantry Cranes : These types have one or two vertical legs which support the horizontal bridge. The bridge of the gantry crane has one or more hoists that help in vertical lifting. Gantries are available in a variety of sizes. Double gantry, half gantries and cantilever gantries are the different types of gantries. As the name suggests, double gantry cranes have two legs. In a half gantry crane, there is a single leg on one end of the bridge, and the other end is supported by a rail mounted on the wall or any other structural member. The bridge in a cantilever gantry crane extends beyond the length of the support legs. These types are generally used outdoors where it is not convenient to erect an overhead runway.

Jib Cranes : It consists of a hoist mounted on a horizontal cantilever beam which is supported by a vertical column. The horizontal beam is pivoted about the vertical axis formed by the column to provide a horizontal sweep for the machine. The beam acts as a track for the hoist trolley to provide radial travel along the length of the beam. The horizontal sweep of a jib crane is circular or semi-circular. The hoist provides vertical lifting and lowering movement. Hoist which is used for lifting can move along the entire length of the jib. The arm of the jib machine can rotate up to 360°

Other commonly used types:

Stacker Cranes are more or less similar to bridge cranes except that, instead of a hoist, they use a mast with forks or a platform to handle unit loads. It is ultimately a crane with a fork lift type mechanism used in automated warehouses. It moves on a track in an aisle of the warehouse and the fork can be raised or lowered to any of the levels of a storage rack and can be extended into the rack to store and retrieve the products. It is used especially when more height has to be reached.

A loader crane is a hydraulically-powered articulated arm fitted to a truck or trailer, and is mainly used for loading or unloading of the vehicles.

Bulk-handling cranes are designed to carry a shell grab or bucket, rather than using a hook or a hoist. They are used for bulk goods, such as industrial liquids, coal, minerals, etc.

The Structure of a Gantry Crane

A gantry crane has a similar structure to a gate. A gantry crane is characterised by its flexibility. It is made out of a  basic frame, a cross beam and a trolley. The particularity of a portable gantry crane is that its frame can be driven along at least one axis. There are also mobile gantry cranes, like container trucks.

Their basic frame contains four legs. These four mobile supports are connected by a cross beam. The supports and the cross beam are usually made out of steel profiles. The alternative is to use large box girders for the cross beam. With large gantry cranes, two of the supports are fixed and the other supports are connected by a slide bearing to the cross beam. Thereby, any changes in length due to fluctuating temperature are balanced out. A trolley is integrated onto the cross beam, which drives the component used to carry loads. The trolley contains a spool and a motor, to which the lifting cable, rope or chain is attached.

Characteristics of a Gantry Crane

A gantry crane’s 4-legged structure makes it particularly suited to move heavy loads over long distances. Revolving tower cranes can move loads within their working area. Thereby, they are dependent on the addition weight from the goods they are carrying. Revolving tower cranes are restricted in terms of how high they can lift very heavy loads, and this needs to be taken into account by the operator. However, these cranes always have their  centre of gravity in between their supporting legs. There is hardly any danger of the crane tipping over due to a load being wrongly lifted or stopped. However, this is only the case when the crane is correctly operated! Some of these cranes can support more than 40t!

The disadvantage of a portal crane is that it requires  a lot of space and it has a very elaborate construction. It requires around four times as many machine elements as a tower crane. If a track-based system is also used, then the installation of a gantry crane becomes very demanding. A standard hoist is used for very demanding tasks, for example, when storing finished concrete workpieces, steel coils and slabs outdoors.

Types of Gantry Cranes

The smallest and simplest portal crane is used in automobile workshops. They are  manually operated and are used to safely lift engines. Even with such small dimensions, they are known for their stability. There are hardly any medium-sized gantry type of cranes. For lifting operations in indoor industrial settings, bridge cranes and overhead crane are used instead of portal cranes. Gantry cranes are mainly used outdoors. They can have enormous dimensions; heights of up to 30 metres are not rare. A special type of gantry crane is a loading truck for high sea containers. These trucks are fully mobile and can reach every point within a workspace, even if it is several thousand square metres large. Other special constructions include combined designs, where a tower crane is mounted into the carriage of a gantry crane. These types of cranes are called level luffing cranes and are mainly used to load ships.

Working with a Gantry Crane

Gantry cranes are manually operated using  remote control or with an integrated driver’s cab. Small gantry cranes that are used for workshops do not require any specific kind of qualification; basic training is sufficient. However, larger loading cranes can only be used by operators with a certificate. The TÜV offers this necessary training. The bigger the crane, the more delayed and cumbersome its reactions are to the controls. There would be a very high risk of danger for both humans and the machine, if a gantry crane, which carries incredibly heavy loads, were to be operated by any untrained or unskilled workers.  Particularly tricky loads are those that shake or vibrate when being moved. This occurs due when the acceleration and force goes beyond the loads own weight. If this occurs when the maximum weight is being carried, then the crane can be pushed over capacity. During training, a crane driver would learn how to react in such a situation and how to bring the load under control.

Machine operated gantry cranes have to follow the machine guidelines. These, and the specific norms for cranes, regularly review the lifting units. Even though the movement of a gantry crane only runs in three axes, the adjustment of loads impacts the whole structure. This means that they require a lot of regular checks and maintenance.

Using a Jib Crane

A slewing jib crane is installed in a certain position, around which heavy loads need to be regularly lifted and moved in order to facilitate jib crane installation. A typical area of operation for this type of crane is around production and machine tools that need to be loaded with heavy transport containers. Industrial saws and cutting machines like water, plasma or flame cutters are commonly equipped with a jib crane. With their help, the delivered components can be easily placed on the work table and then taken away again after the process is complete. Free standing jib cranes are ideal for specific and reoccurring uses. Slewing jib cranes are most commonly used indoors. For outdoor operations, slewing jib cranes are often built to be large and powerful. An example of a portable jib crane design, which is decidedly built for outdoor use is the boat crane.

The Construction of a Jib Crane

There are two types of jib cranes. Column-mounted slewing cranes consist of a stable foot, upon which an extended arm is mounted. There is a trolley on the extended arm, which hosts the lifting mechanism. A wall-mounted slewing jib crane does not have its own stand but it is directly mounted on a wall or a column.
Slewing jib cranes intended for indoor use are generally equipped with a horizontal cantilever arm and trolley. Luffing and derrick cranes, in the form of a slewing crane, are not overhead cranes. When used indoors, slewing cranes with a wide overhanging outer boom require a lot of space, which further restricts the crane's freedom of movement. Luffing and derrick cranes are also available as free standingjib cranes for outdoor use. You can find specific information through jib crane plans.

The Size of a Jib Crane

Revolving cranes have a counterweight, which is used to even out the torque that occurs when a load is lifted. Gantry and overhead cranes are particularly stable because the distribution of the lifted loads are distributed over several different points of support. Both of these are not available for the crane jib. For this reason, their support and structural system is particularly massive. Slewing crane's columns and cantilever arms can be very large. These constructions allow this type of crane to lift very heavy loads. The stability of the cantilever arm is reached by using torsionally rigid double T beams, box profiles or welded triangular constructions. Jib crane components can be massive, but their construction is very simple. This means that if slewing cranes are bought used, they can be easily modified. The booms (particularly when used with a double T beams) can easily be shortened or switched out for a longer arm. The cranes that are most commonly installed in industrial halls are primarily made out of normal components, which can be easily ordered. For the particularly massive special cranes, the manufacturers can usually help to figure out how best fit the crane in its area of operation. The producers of jib cranes and jib crane parts usually have excellent customer service and also give good advice with regards to buying their used products.

Working with a Jib Crane & Slewing Jib Crane

The size of a jib crane, just like other cranes, determines how qualified the operator needs to be. Simple wall-mounted slewing cranes have an electric motor in the lifting unit. Therefore, pushing the trolley or moving the crane can be undertaken with muscle power. High-quality jib cranes are so well equipped, that they can still be manually adjusted, even with loads of over hundreds of kilogrammes.

In sensitive areas or with loads of up to several tonnes, a portable crane has an engine that powers the trolley and the movement of the beam. These types of cranes are much more expensive than their simple, manually-operated counterparts. This is because these machines are only built with particularly high-quality components. A weight, weighing about a tonne, is located at the tip of the beam, which already gives the crane its torque momentum on the radial and axial bearings of the crane. As the crane turns, there is a further torque in a transverse direction. The applied forces multiply to enormous levels of pressure tension on the bearings and the slewing gear, which puts a strain on all the constructive components. The highest quality components are used so that this can be permanently and safely prevented from happening.

Hall slewing jib cranes are general controlled via a cable or remote control. A crane operating license is required for this type of controlling system. Every operation, which uses this type of crane, needs to appoint safety officers or machines officers. They are trained to provide briefings and internal training on how to operate a truck jib crane. For training on how to operate a crane, there are associations that can provide training materials. With a bit of practice, it is possible to learn how to correctly work with a slewing crane in a few hours.

Outdoor cranes, like loading or boat cranes are controlled from their own driver's cab. Before operating these cranes, one must have an official crane operating license. The independent testing institutes usually have this type of training available.

Accessories For Wall-mounted Slewing Crane And Free Standing Jib Cranes

Jib cranes can be equipped with all types of accessories. In addition to the common beams and chains, permanent or electromagnetic grippers and special lifting devices are available in jib crane kits such as a wall-mounting equipment or even special free standing accessories which makes it possible. Scales and sensors can be useful tools for receiving and sorting goods. If the crane has been optimally suited to fit the job crane specifications, then it is a economical and highly efficient tool.

Buying Used Jib Cranes

Due to their simple construction, portable jib cranes can be bought used. The vertical column and the boom need to be completely straight. Aluminium measuring bars can be used to check this. Crooked, buckled or warped cranes should not be used. A bent boom suggests that the used portable jib crane for sale has been overloaded and this can impact all the crane's components. If the crane has been disassembled, then the bearings and bearing supports can no longer be noise and backlash free. Therefore, damaged cranes should not be used and should be recycled.

A used jib crane should always have a certification label from an independent monitoring organisation. One should be cautious with freshly painted used cranes. If the jib crane for sale has been repaired using welding, this can often no longer be seen under the paint. If these repairs were not undertaken correctly, there is a large risk that the crane could break. Therefore, a good crane with strong indications that it has been used is better than one that has been freshly painted. You can find many different used jib cranes for sale on TradeMachines, including for instance portable jib crane or mobile jib crane, small jib crane, floor mounted jib crane, hydraulic jib crane and telescopic jib crane. Overhead Crane - Lifting Device for Industrial Settings

Most factory buildings have an overhead crane. These can also be called an “underslung crane” or a “bridge crane”. The name is based on the structure of the crane: it looks like a bridge. Two stable constructions are found on either side of the workspace, and the cross beam upon which the crane travels is connected by the two side structures. A Goliath or gantry crane is very similar to a bridge crane, but they stand on supports containing wheels. With bridge cranes, the cross beam lies directly on the crane runway.

Bridge / Overhead Crane Safty

A bridge crane requires a stable track. These are most commonly projected out from the concrete masonry. However, it is not a big problem if this design is not used, as a workspace can be equipped with this type of crane using simple steel beams. The crane runway usually runs along the length of the hall, which depicts the x-axis of the working space of the crane. The overhead crane has a really simple structure. One or two bridge elements span over the intended crane runway, which is where the trolley is. A lifting device is connected to the trolley. The direction of the bridge and the trolley’s runway depicts the y-axis of the bridge crane. This is usually the width of the hall. The direction in which the load is lifted is determined by the pull of the trolley. This is the z-axis of the crane. This means that all areas within a hall could be reached. Just like gantry cranes, bridge cranes are characterised by the fact that they move their loads within their focus areas. Thereby, they are very safe and do not cause any damage to the load. The safety of overhead cranes makes them ideal for many uses. Tower cranes, on the other hand, could fall over if they are overloaded. The bridge crane also doesn’t take up any space within a workspace; it is not in the way, when not being used.

Working with an Overhead Crane

This type of crane is operated by driver cabs, cables or remote control. Operators should have completed at least one in-house training day with the crane before operating it independently. The basic operating principles can be learned very quickly but there is a lot to learn in terms of the necessary precautions for safely operating a crane. It is very important to practice moving goods quietly and without vibration. It is particularly important to learn which goods can be carried and which cannot. Most accidents with cranes occur because of limited knowledge in this area. For example, cylinder trolleys for blow torches or welding equipment can only be lifted with specially customised lifting devices. Even though it seems simple, working with a crane cannot be underestimated.

Sheet Lifters used with Overhead Crane

One of the popular types of overhead crane uses is the sheet lifters, a crane attachment that specialised in lifting metal sheets or any other material sheets. This specific type of crane, the sheet lifters can be attached to almost every overhead crane or bridge crane out there. 

Maintaining an Overhead Crane

A bridge crane is a heavy-duty piece of equipment, which is exposed to very high levels of wear and tear along its whole structure. This is particularly the case with the heavy components such as slabs, coils or steel pipes. A regular, or at least annual, check up is required for the operation of the crane. Due to its simple construction, the crane can be repaired with relatively few resources. Depending on the circumstances, many components have a limited working lifespan. This is particularly the case for the lifting equipment, like the rope and stops. When buying a second-hand bridge crane for sale, it is important to make sure that these components are well documented. If not, they should be exchanged. It is also important to look for visible damages when buying a used crane. For example, if the cross-beams are crooked, these cannot be used. Maintenance work must be undertaken by professional maintenance technicians. Cranes have special lubrication points then need to be regularly tended to. The working lifespan of the crane will significantly increase if this is done regularly and correctly.

Characteristics of an electric forklift truck

Propane Forklifts - What do I need to know about them?

Forklifts are powered via three different methods: battery (electric forklift), diesel, and LPG. Every type of forklift has specific advantages and disadvantages. Electric forklifts are very quiet and emission-free. Therefore, they are the best type of forklift for indoor transportation. Forklifts with a diesel engine are very economical and are characterised as being able to generate high levels of power without consuming very much energy, but they are not suitable for indoor use. 

LPG forklifts are just as quiet as electric forklifts, and also have clean combustion, meaning that they can be used in enclosed rooms. This is possible because of the modern engine management system and the use of a clean propane gas as a fuel. However, carbon dioxide emissions can never be avoided when it comes to using a combustion engine. Propane gas is a fossil fuel, built upon carbon fuel, which when oxidised turns into the desired fuel. When using LPG forklifts indoors, it is highly recommended to have an effective exhaust system. 

The structure of an LPG forklift

An LPG forklift consists of a slightly tilted lifting device with an attached fork, an engine, two axles with wheels, a driver's seat and a counterweight. Just like all forklifts, LPG forklifts are also steered by their back wheels. This means that they have a very tight turning circle and are easy to manoeuvre in small spaces. A stable driver's cab with a roll-over protection system protects the driver from being buried by the forklift if it tips over. 

To refuel an LPG forklift, the propane gas tank has to be switched. This requires a large screw key. The propane gas tank is often installed at the rear of the vehicle. It is either attached with belts or a clamping system, which is easy to open. With some practice, a propane gas tank can be switched in less than two minutes.

Backhoes are also referred by different names such as diggers, backhoe loaders or loader excavators. It will be uncommon to find a construction site without a backhoe loader as it is one of the widely machinery in the field of construction engineering. These backhoes come in a variety of sizes, ranging from those that can fit in very small areas to those that are used in heavy duty operations such as river dredging, construction of bridges and residential units. Backhoes also called as tractor loader backhoes are so versatile in their functionality as it combines the functions of several machines and that is the reason why a backhoe loader is one of the most common used contruction equipment employed in the building industry.

Backhoes and its Construction

Backhoe loaders are made up of three major units namely a tractor, a front end loader and a backhoe. The design of these backhoes is a cab placed on a rotating platform that has wheels or tracks at its base for movement from one place to another. It has a regular boom with the bucket facing the driver’s cab. The cab which is attached to the boom is able to rotate 360 degrees allowing for digging anywhere around the loader excavator. The placement of the bucket allows the driver to dig up soil towards the backhoe and it also gives a good view to the driver of the movement of the bucket. The backhoe bucket can also be replaced with powered attachments such as a breaker, grapple, auger, or a stump grinder. Many backhoes feature quick attach mounting systems and auxiliary hydraulic circuits for simplified attachment mounting and retracting.
