START HOLE EROSION MACHINES

EDM and it’s Types

Electrical Discharge Machining is a controlled material removal process for manufacturing geometrically complex or hard material parts that are extremely difficult to machine by conventional machining processes. EDM is one of the most extensively used non-conventional machining process because of its increasing ability to machine metals at higher speeds. It is a thermal erosion process which works on the principle of spark erosion. Several recurring electrical discharges are created between the cutting tool which in this case is an electrode and the work piece which is electrically conductive. The process takes place in the presence of a dielectric fluid. EDM can be broadly classified into three major types namely: Wire cut EDM, Die Sinking or Ram EDM and Start hole erosion EDM.

What is Start Hole Erosion EDM?

Small Hole EDM is an improved method of utilizing EDM to drill small holes in conductive material at speeds that are typically 10 times faster than those achieved with conventional Die Sinker or Ram EDM process which was earlier used to drilling of holes by electrical discharge machining. Small Hole EDM is now recognized and accepted as the third method of EDM Machining along with Sinker EDM and Wire EDM. Small hole EDM drilling, also known as fast hole EDM drilling, hole popper, and start hole EDM drilling, uses a rotating tubular electrode with a diameter of 0.1 mm to 6 mm to drill holes by means of electrical discharge machining by eroding material from the work piece in the presence of a water dielectric. These holes may have a depth-to-diameter ratio of 30 to 1 or higher. Tubular electrodes are rotated at speeds of about 100 RPM while drilling. As the electrical discharges occur, this rotation aids in flushing and provides for uniform electrode wear.

History of Start Hole Erosion EDM

High-speed EDM hole drilling was designed especially for fast, accurate small and deep hole drilling applications. Small holes that were once almost impossible to drill by conventional machine tools are now being performed with ease. Conventional Sinker EDM was successfully applied for the drilling of small holes, however the process was always considered to be very slow when compared to conventional drilling. Then came the invention of a specialized EDM process for the drilling of small holes in the late 1970’s. Start hole erosion EDM drilling which was considered to be the last resort for drilling of small holes is now widely used for production work. This can be attributed to the higher drilling speeds of up to 2 inches per minute achievable with the process nowadays. And holes can be drilled in any electrically conductive material, be it hard or soft including carbides. With the capability of drilling through virtually any conductive material, the use of this technology is continually expanding.

Construction and Working of Start Hole Erosion EDM Machine

The basic elements constituting a start hole erosion EDM machine are:

  • Extrusion Stainless steel work table
  • Rotating spindle
  • Drill chuck or collet system for holding electrodes
  • Ceramic or diamond guides
  • Power supply with control panel
  • Capacitor box
  • Dielectric fluid pump

Start hole erosion EDM works on the same principle of spark erosion as the wire EDM or die sinker EDM. An electrical discharge is produced across the gap between the contactless electrode and the work piece thereby eroding the material from the job. The process consists of using a precision tubular electrode (generally brass or copper) mounted into the drill chuck located on the "Z" axis and held in location on top of the work piece by the ceramic guide. The top of the work piece is located and the drilling depth is set. The electrode rotation is turned on and the deionized water solution, which is pressurized between 50 and 100 kg/cm2, is sent through the tubular electrode as a flushing agent. The power supply parameters are set-which normally consist of on-time, off-time, peak current and amount of capacitance. At this point, the discharge is turned on to begin the drilling cycle. At the end of the drilling cycle, the discharge is turned off and the "Z" axis is retracted above the work piece. A servo drive is used to maintain the gap between the electrode and work piece. If the electrode touches the work piece, a short occurs and in such cases, the servo drive retracts the electrode.

APPLICATIONS OF START HOLE EROSION EDM PROCESS

Small hole drilling EDM has got wider field of applications. As the process is capable of producing burr free holes, it eliminates the usage of any secondary deburring process. And it is considered to be the most cost effective method for drilling fast and accurate holes in any conductive metals. Although originally conceived as a method of economically producing small holes with large depth-to-diameter ratios, Small Hole EDM is now utilized in just about any situation in many industries where conventional drilling a small hole is normally difficult: Automotive- Diesel fuel injection nozzles, Textile– Fiber spinning nozzles, Wire drawing– Small draw dies, Aerospace– Turbine blade cooling holes, Semiconductor– Silicon masks, Tool, Die, & Mold– Small Hole EDM drilling is ideal for putting ejector holes in hardened punches, coolant holes in cutting tools, vent holes in molds,wire EDM starting holes. And as many of the start hole erosion EDM machines utilize distilled water as the flushing agent, it opens up new applications in the medical field as well.

ONA ELECTRO EROSION, Heun Funkenerosion GmbH, Mitsubishi EDM, ANG International, POSALUX, Aristech, Current EDM are some of the worldwide manufacturers of small hole drilling EDM machines.

Knee Type Milling Machine

Classification of Milling Machines

Milling can be defined as the process of removing material from a work piece by feeding it against a rotary multi point cutting tool called as the milling cutter. Milling machines are the most versatile machines used in the industries for the machining of flat surfaces, spirals, helixes, grooves, slots and complex contours etc. and they are basically classified as being horizontal or vertical indicating the axis of the milling machine spindle. Milling machines can also be classified based on the configuration of the work table or bed as:

  • Knee type
  • Bed type
  • Planer type
  • Rotary table type

Knee Type Milling Machine Configuration

Knee mill machine is a commonly used general purpose machine in factories. The name, “Knee type milling machine” is because of the fact that the work table is supported on a knee-like casting which can slide in a vertical direction along the column to which it is rigidly clamped to in a position where the milling head and milling machine spindle are properly adjusted for operation. The principal components of a knee milling machine are:

  • Work table – The work piece is clamped onto the work table using the T-slots.
  • Saddle – The function of a saddle is to support the work table
  • Knee – It supports the saddle and gives the table vertical movements, thereby responsible for the adjustment of the depth of cut.
  • Overarm – It is used in horizontal machines to accommodate different arbor lengths.
  • Milling Head – It contains the spindle and cutter holders. The head may be fixed or vertically adjustable in vertical machines depending on the purpose of use.

Motion in a Knee Type Milling Machine

The milling machine's knee travels vertically, rides up or down the column on a rigid track also supporting the saddle and table. The saddle resting upon the knee moves in and out from the column, while the worktable traverses to the right or left upon the saddle for feeding the work piece past the milling cutter. The table may be manually controlled or power fed. Additionally, the ram, at the top of the column, which supports the milling head containing the motor, tool head, speed and feed controls, quill and spindle can be moved both in and out from the column and can be tilted for angular milling and drilling as well. The non-rotating quill holds the rotating spindle.

Knee Type Milling Machine Types

Knee milling machines can be further sub-divided into two types as horizontal and vertical machines depending on the axis of rotation. The plain vertical machines are characterized by a spindle located vertically, parallel to the column face, and mounted in a sliding head in which the feeding can be done up and down. Modern vertical milling machines are designed in such a way that the entire milling head can also be swivelled to a certain extent for the purpose of exclusively working on angular surfaces.

In a plain horizontal milling machine, column contains the drive motor and gearing and milling spindle is fixed at a particular position horizontally . An adjustable overhead arm containing one or more arbor supports projects forward from the top of the column. The primary function of the arm and its supports is to stabilize long arbors. Supports can be moved along the overhead arm to support the arbor wherever necessary depending on the position of the milling cutter. With various attachments, knee type milling machines can be used for various operations like boring, slotting, reaming, circular milling and drilling.

The Function of a Metal Bandsaw and Cutting Saws

A metal cutting saw is made out of a saw blade, whose material has to be harder than the material of the workpiece it will be cutting. Only the tips of the teeth have to be harder, but a diamond coating on the saw blade can enhance the metal saw. Saw blades for metal cutting saws have extremely small teeth. The size of the teeth is due to the hard and tough material that they are made of. Metal can only be separated in small stages. Large teeth would be bend immediately. The saw blade of hacksaw or metal bandsaw and reciprocating saws are in the form of a band. With circular saws they are round. Alternatively to a toothed saw blade, a rotating separator sheet on an angle grinder can also be used. 

Metal saws range from simple, manual hacksaws through to powered horizontal or vertical band saws and circular saws. When looking for a metal saw for sale, it's best to give some thought to the exact nature of the jobs you'll want to use it for and tailor your purchase accordingly. Vertical band saws are particularly useful in cutting curving or unusual shapes. Additionally, there are abrasive saws, otherwise known as metal chop saw, which are conveniently light and portable. These items have found a great deal of favour on building sites and smaller workshops as they can perform jobs previously done chiefly by the use of acetylene torches.

The Structure of a Metal Cutting Saw

Mechanical saws consist of a saw blade, a clamp and a motor. Electric circular saws, bandsaws and hacksaws are stationary machines, which are equipped with their own work table and stop. Thereby, metal cutting saws are set up for a variety of tasks can produce very precise cuts. The preparation of a metal block for further processing on a  lathe or milling machine can be undertaken on a stationary saw. Just like all metal cutting machines, electric saws are also equipped with a cooling lubricant. Reciprocating saws are electric hand tools, used to free-handedly separate metal. They are commonly used to recycle automobiles because they can easily be used to cut through the vehicle's beams. Their advantage is that they are free on one side . This means that they can be used for complex materials without any problems. These metal hand saws can be used to process tubes and profiles on-site. Reciprocating saws need to produce very precise cuts. The one-sided open saw blade tends to deflect in a lateral direction, which means that the precision of the cut can only occur within the range of a millimetre.

Applications & Characteristics of Different Types of Metal Sawing Machines

Metal cutting saws are used to cut metal blocks, profiles, pipes, bars and grooved pieces of sheet metal. These are used to cut intermediary stage products to the extent that they are then ready for further processing. Therefore, metal sawing technology is a very important tool for every metalworking workshop. Precise cuts and the production of complex constructions can be ensured with the implementation of additional applications like guides.

Metal bandsaws have the advantage that they do not heat up. The band creates heat during the sawing process, but this is continually expelled into the surrounding air. A metal band saw is suited for precisely cutting tubes, bars and profiles. Metal band saws only require a short cutting surface and can be set to process specific points.

Automatic hacksaws generally require a cooling agent. They are characterised by their ability to produce very precise cuts and are more suited for long cuts. Hacksaws are particularly suited to cut metal blocks since the saw maintains the same position throughout the cutting process. In most cases, a cooling agent is required to cool the saw blade and the workpiece, and to remove the chippings.

Just like metal cutting saws, circular saws and angle grinders are also used to cut pipes and profiles. Their advantage is that they have very high cutting speeds. They are less suited to cut metal blocks. The height of the saw blade defines the maximum thickness of the block. Metal cutting circular saws often overheat and jam because cooling agents cannot be easily applied.

There are also smaller tools like the metal cutter that can be handled manually that adapt to smaller needs.

Metal Cutting Machine Operation and Safety

Saws are used to prepare intermediary metal workpieces. These workpieces will be further processed at different stations, and so it is highly required that the cut metal workpiece is very precise. However, adjustments are also manageable. Therefore, metal cutting saws can be operated by assistants. A thorough briefing is very important. Clamping in the workpiece correctly, and adjusting the sawing and feed speeds, need to be well understood and practised by the worker. The attention to work safety is very important. Wear eye protection and suitable protective clothing is obligatory. Metal cutting saws are great machines for first learning how to process metal. Just like all cutting machines, these saws create a large amount of dirt and waste. The correct and thorough cleaning and maintenance of these machines needs to be understood by the operator and then reliably undertaken. Normally, this only consists of switching the saw blade. A metal cutting hand saw is constructed in such a way, that this can be very easily undertaken.

However, unskilled assistants should not operate these machines unsupervised. Hacksaws make wide sweeping oscillations and the saw band of a metal bandsaw can suddenly rip. Both are associated with a high risk of injury. All workers need to be briefed on the risks of injury associated with a metal cutting saws before using these machine.

Development and History of the Grinding Machine

Grinding machines are most commonly used for hard materials. Grinder machine suited, for example, for processing hard metal or hardened steel workpieces. The grinding material used is finely ground and is either bound together in the form of a grinding wheel or band, or is loose (e.g. during lapping).Using sharp grains of sand to remove hard materials is dated back to the Stone Age. Rotating grinding stones have been used to sharpen bells from at least the 9th century. The first grinding machines were used in the 12th century as grinding mills, which were converted from conventional grinders.

Areas of Application of Metal Grinding Machines

There are a number of different types of grinding machines for sale for sheet metal work, and they are applied for various tasks. Important characteristics to note when looking at a grinding machine are the location of the contact area between the workpiece and tool, and where the cutting movement and main feed direction are situated.  The cutting area is the differentiating factor between side grinding and peripheral grinding. The direction of the movements determines which process (i.e. up grinding, slide grinding or pendulum grinding) can be undertaken. The actual movement of the cut or the feeding movements are controlled by the rotating, and sometimes oscillating, tool. Surface grinders and cylindrical grinders can be used for all general applications. A surface grinder is used to create even surfaces and a cylindrical grinder is used for workpieces with rotational symmetry. There are internal and external cylindrical grinding machines available; universal cylindrical grinding machines are a combination of the two. The centre less cylindrical grinder is a special construction with a high stock removal rate and reduced idle time. Tool and form grinders are particularly precise in their work and are used to produce or refurbish tools. For example, tool grinders are used to sharpen drills, lathe chisels and mill cutters. Gear grinding machines are used to produce the teeth for gears. Belt grinders are used to produce surfaces of the highest quality, to engrave cast and punched pieces, and clean sheet metal. For workpieces that have very high requirements for their surface quality, shape and dimensional accuracy can be processed using honing and lapping machines.

The grinding process is used to remove large volumes of excess metal in a relatively short time and to produce items with a high surface quality. Operators can control the movement of the grinding head across a workpiece fixed into position. Alternatively the workpiece can be moved while the abrasive wheel remains fixed. Here are the main types of grinding machines that can be located and purchased with ease at used industrial machinery auctions.   

Grinding Machine Types

  • Cylindrical Grinding machines: These are the most common type. These are used to shape the exterior of an object, such as a cylinder or a crankshaft, having a central axis of rotation. Cylindrical grinding can be divided into four types; outside diameter, inside diameter, creep feed, plunge and centreless grinding.
  • Centerless Grinding machines: These differ from centred grinding machines in that there is no spindle on which to secure the workpiece. Instead, it is set in place between a pair of rotary grinding wheels. This process is noted for its speed and can be divided into three main types; through feed, end feed and in feed.
  • Jig Grinding machines
  • Surface Grinding machines: are used to produce precision ground surfaces to a high degree of precision. These are divided into peripheral grinders utilising horizontal spindles, wheel face grinders with vertical spindles, and disc grinders available in both horizontal and vertical spindle types.
  • Belt Grinding machines
  • Internal Grinding machines
  • Tool and Gear Grinding machines: Tool grinding machines, otherwise known as cutter and tool grinders, are very versatile items of equipment that are used to sharpen tool bits, milling cutters and various other cutting tools. They can be used for various grinding processes, including quite complex forms. Modern grinding machines are CNC tool grinders, generally with five axes.

The conventional hacksaw is used for wood- and metalworking. Today, the further developed machine-powered hacksaws are used in various branches of industry. The industrial hacksaw can pretty much saw all materials.

What characterises the hacksaw?

This type of saw has specific characteristics, like the U-shaped clamp, which is open on the bottom. A saw blade, which is fixed in between the ends of the clamp, cuts the various materials using lifting and pushing movements.

The hack saw has been developed over 4,700 years. Materials have been cut by hacksaws for a millennium. Relics and debris from the Bronze Age provide evidence to show that this type of sawing process was used by the ancient Egyptians. The power hacksaw was developed in the industrial revolution and through the introduction of the steam engine. The rapid growth of industrial production led to the development of the electric hacksaw, which now been transformed into a fully automatic machine.

What advantages does the hacksaw have and where is it used?

The function of a hacksaw is very simple and has a variety of advantages. The saw blade, which is fixed between the joints, is very taut due to the tension. Therefore, there is no chance of it bending. Additional, incredibly narrow saw blades can be used, which ensure a minimal loss in the workpiece’s material, and allows for minimal cutting processes to be undertaken. Due to stability, the clamp is thicker than the hack saw and it restricts the workpiece due to its height and width.

When using a hand hack saw or junior hack saw, the lifting movement is always an idle stroke. This means that only half of the work is actually productive. Materials that are difficult to cut can be processed using a broaching process, which is where only a few saw teeth are required. The hand operated hacksaw is mainly used in the wood and metal industry. Common types of saws used in woodworking are the jig saw, branch saw and frame saw. The hand-held hacksaw is a common tool used for metalworking. The lifting and pushing movements of the power hack saw is powered using a motor and a gear hub, which transforms the rotation movement. The base frame, made out of grey cast iron or cast steel contains all of the mechanical components. The workpiece can be clamped onto the saw table using a hand operated, pneumatic or hydraulic vice. A stop is used to ensure a high level of accuracy in repeated length measurements. The machine’s saw clamp is loaded on the side and guides the sawing and lifting movement of the saw blade; the lifting movement occur in the opposite direction of the cutting movement. Almost all materials can be cut using a hacksaw, and power hack saws are often used to saw steel bars. When sawing metal, a pipe or other construction for the supply of cooling agent, is available to ensure that the workpiece and saw blade remain cool.

The hacking saw is mainly used in machine and steel construction, for cutting workpieces into the required length. A common method is to choose dimensions that are somewhat bigger than the dimensions of the finished workpiece. This allows for the work piece to be cut into the desired length during finishing touches using a lathe or milling machine. One example is cutting tool steel for trapezoidal screws, which are used in many different machine tools.

Who discovered the potential of the hacksaw and established themselves as a manufacturer of hacksaws?

There is an enormous demand for industrial hacksaws in the big industry branches of machine and steel construction. Those who have specialised themselves in producing hacksaws include MITTWEIDA, KASTO, BEHRINGER, STANDARD, SAW, WMW, and WEISEL. The hacksaw has continued to be developed since the time of the ancient Egyptians in order to be optimised to suit all kinds of materials and current scientific knowledge.

The structure and function of a metal cutting circular saw

All hand-held circular saws, and even most machine tools, can only undertake discontinuous sawing operations. These metal circular saws require an idle stroke for every working stroke. The cut is restricted by the length of the saw blade, after which the saw blade needs to move in the other direction and be guided back to the starting position. There are only a few saws and saw blades that can be used in both directions. The circular saw does not have this restriction because it has a seemingly infinitely long saw blade. When looking at the typology of machine tools, the circular saw is somewhat derived from the milling machine. The circular saw blade is, in principle, a thinner rolling mill with a larger diameter. The disadvantage of this is the depth to which the metal cutting circular saw blades are inserted in the cut. For this reason, circular saw for sale can only produce particularly straight cuts. Due to the continual operation, small circular saws usually are able to produce a very even cut.

History and Development From a Small Circular Saw to a Circular Saw Table

Different types and designs of circular saws and their areas of applicationThe invention of the circular saw cannot be historically confirmed. It appears in patents from the 18th century, but is not patented itself. Therefore, it must have been around earlier. The steam engines at the beginning of the 19th century provided enough power to drive the very large circular saws in sawmills, which had saw blades with diameters of up to 3 metres. The hand-held circular saw was based on an invention from 1923 and led to the company SKILSAW being founded.

Due to their continuous method of operation, an electric circular saw has a higher average level of power than saws that change their direction of movement, like hacksaws. Circular saw blades are only suited for straight cuts, and so they are used in all areas where a particularly high cutting performance and a precise, straight cut is required. There are hand-held, battery-powered circular saws available for using on the go. Special types of hand circular saw are used for cutting cement, asphalt or natural stones. If a higher level of cutting power is required, e.g. on construction sites, then circular saw benches can be used. With this type of device, the saw is fixed onto a work table, called circular saw table, and the saw blade protrudes through the table's panel from the bottom. With a panel saw, the workpiece moves into a guide that is usually put into the exact position required using the help of built-in scales. For particularly hard materials, a circular saw blade with diamond-studded teeth can be used. Surface Grinding Machines

In the surface grinding process, the grinding wheel revolves on a spindle; and the work piece, mounted on either a reciprocating or a rotary table, is brought into contact with the grinding wheel. Though a surface grinding machine is the most preferred machines for finishing flat surfaces, some types of surface grinders are also capable of producing contour surface with formed grinding wheel.

Types of Surface Grinders

Based on the movement of the tables and the orientation of the grinding wheel, the surface grinding machines can be classified into four different types of surface grinding techniques:

  • Horizontal spindle and reciprocating table – With this type of surface grinder machine, the work moves back and forth under the grinding wheel. The grinding wheel is mounted on a horizontal spindle and cuts on its periphery as it contacts the work piece. It is the most widely used surface grinder and they are capable of accommodating very smaller to large work parts.
  • Vertical spindle and reciprocating table – The grinding operation is similar to that of face milling on a vertical milling machine. In this machine a cup shaped wheel grinds the work piece over its full width using end face of the wheel. When compared to the previous type of peripheral grinding, higher material removal rate can be achieved using this machine as it brings more grits into action. Bedways of an engine lathe and other long and narrow castings are most suited for grinding in this machine.
  • Horizontal spindle and rotary table – In this type of surface grinder, the work piece rotates 360 degrees on a rotary table underneath the wheelhead. The wheelhead moves across the work piece to provide the necessary cross feed movements. But there is an inherent limitation in the usage of this machine, it is not capable of grinding larger jobs. However, by swivelling the worktable, concave, convex or tapered surface grinding services can be produced on individual part.
  • Vertical spindle and rotary table – Vertical spindle machines use cup, cylinder, or segmented wheels. Many of these machines are equipped with two or more grinding heads to successively rough, semi-finish, and finish large castings, forgings, and welded fabrications in one rotation of the work table. The vertical surface grinding machine is mostly suitable for small work pieces in large quantities.

What is a Gear Hobbing Machine :  Gear manufacturing processes can be grouped in two categories: Gear forming & Gear generation. In gear form cutting, the cutting edge of the cutting tool has a shape identical with the shape of the space between the gear teeth. Form milling & Broaching are the gear forming processes. In gear generating, the tooth flanks are generated as an outline of the subsequent positions of the cutter, which resembles in shape the mating gear in the gear pair as in gear hobbing & gear shaping. Gear hobbing is a machining process in which gear teeth are progressively generated by a series of cuts with a helical multi point cutting tool called as hob. Hobbing is the most preferred industrial process for cutting gear teeth than any other teeth forming processes. Almost teeth of all types of gears like spur, helical, worm, sometimes special forms are cut using hobbing machines. The hob and the gear blank rotate continuously just as in the meshing of two gears until all teeth of the gear blank are cut.

Cutting Principle

The cutting of a gear with a hobbing machine is a continuous operation and four to five teeth can be cut at a time on a progressive basis. To start cutting a gear, the rotating hob is fed inward until the proper setting for tooth depth is achieved, then cutting continues until the entire gear is finished. A proportional feed rate is always maintained between the gear blank and hob. The metal is removed from the blank as the hob generates the tooth form. The generating process requires an accurate relationship between various elements of the machine in order to achieve the desired results. The work table rotates in a definite relationship with the rotation of the hub. Index change gears are responsible for the timing of this relation. But in the case of hobbing helical gears, the rotation of the work table is slightly advanced or retarded in relation to the rotation of the axial feed screw with the help of another set of change gears namely differential change gears.

Hobbing vs Shaping

Gear hobbing and shaping are the two major gear generating processes as discussed above. Hobbing produces a series of radial flats based on feed rate of hob across the work while shaping produces a series of straight lines parallel to the axis of the gear. The accuracy of the resultant gears produced by hobbing is with respect to tooth spacing and runout whereas it depends on the tooth form in the case of shaping. Stacking can make hobbing faster than shaping even for gears with narrow face widths. But narrow width jobs can be generated in lesser times with high speed stroking in gear shaping. Hobbing has a major disadvantage of not able to machine internal gears when compared to its counterpart.

Types of Hobbing Machines

The gear hobbing process can be classified into three different types according to the directions of feeding the hob for gear cutting as:

Hobbing with Axial Feed: In this process the gear hob is fed against the gear blank along the face of the blank and parallel to its axis. This kind of feed is used mainly for making spur and helical gears.

Hobbing with Radial Feed: The hob and gear blanks are set with their axis normal to each other in this method. The rotating hob is fed against the gear blank in radial direction or at right angles to the axis of the gear blank. Worm wheels are made predominantly using this method of feeding.

Hobbing with Tangential Feed: In this kind of feeding, the hob is held with its axis horizontal but perpendicular to the axis of the gear blank. The hob is set at full depth of the tooth and then fed forward axially. Thus, the hob is fed tangential to the face of gear blank.

Advantages and Limitations

Some of the prominent advantages of the process of gear hobbing machines are: Gear hobbing is a fast and continuous process so it is realized as economical process as compared to other gear generation processes like shaping. It involves lower production cycle time thereby leading to higher productivity. The process is capable of making a wide variety of gears like spur gear, helical gears, worms, worm gears, splines, sprockets, etc. Indexing process is highly simplified and any number of teeth with consistent accuracy and precision can be made with ease. Also the indexing process is continuous and there is no intermittent motion subsequently eliminating the rise of errors. Gear hobbing is the exclusive process used for generating a special type of gear called harringbone gear. It is highly suitable for both batch and mass production. Several gear blanks, mounted on the same arbor, can be processed simultaneously which leads to cycle time reduction.

Because of the nature and profile of the hob, there is no overheating of the cutting tool as there is ample amount of time available to dissipate the heat. In addition to above mentioned various advantages, one of the major limitation of the process of gear hobbing is that the manufacturing of internal gears is not possible. Some of the splines and serrations require one tooth blocked or removed, which cannot be generated in a gear hobbing machine. Definition of a keyseating machine

A keyseating machine is a cutting machine tool, used to produce internal grooves in hollow profiles. It is used when a lathe or milling machine cannot be used.

The function of a keyseater

A keyseating machine works along a vertical, linear movement and uses a one-sided draw knife for cutting. This removes material off the workpiece bit by bit using an even, downward motion. The width of the groove is determined by the corresponding ground knife. The depth of the groove is determined by the number of strokes. This is why these machines are related to planers. A keyseater is used to create uniform grooves on particularly tight hollow profiles. The form-fitting connection between the knife and the workpiece creates an exact and uniform cutting movement. They are very precise machines; their axes are particularly parallel. The one-sided draw knife uses a cutting, rather than a machining process, which ensures a particularly high quality surface.

Areas of application of keyseating machines

These internal grooves are created for full floating axles, carriers and springs. Another use is the uniform and simultaneous production of internal grooves in a row of workpieces. When simultaneously processing several workpieces in one machine, there is a particularly high level of consistency between the created geometries. Gear teeth and full floating axles are typical components, whose internal grooves are produced using keyseating machines.

The structure of a keyseating machine

The advantage of these machines is that they have a very compact construction. Contrary to expansive lathes or voluminous milling machines, most keyseating machines are no bigger than 2 meters squared. A cover is mounted upon a square base frame made out of either a welded or grey cast iron construction. On top of the cover there is the work table with a clamping device and the tool guide. The machine can be adjusted. This means: the single sided cutting knife is built in; the feed and the speed of the stroke are adjusted; the workpiece is put into place and clamped in; and then the process is started. Once it has started, the cutting work is done almost independently. Contrary to lathes or milling machines, a keyseating machine can have a high rotation speed. Therefore, their processes do not result in any flying chippings. Therefore, keyseating machines can usually be used without a cover or extraction systems. A cooling lubricant extends the working life of the cutting tool. Due to the minimal processing speed, keyseating does not produce as high of temperatures as turning and milling processes. However, the development of heat can lead to expansion of the cutting head and workpiece’s materials. This results in a loss of quality and a high level of wear and tear. Therefore, the use of a cooling lubricant is required for every keyseating process. Keyseaters work either mechanically, hydraulically or by using ball screws. Keyseating machines are not as flexible as lathes or milling machines in processing workpieces. They only undertake their one task – the production of grooves – but with a high level of precision and safety. They are most suited for facilities, which have a high requirement for keyseating processes. Here, keyseating machines can be used in the machine parks instead of milling machines and lathes.

Working with a keyseating machine

Despite the fact that they can run independently, keyseating machines are more suited for trained cutting machine operators, rather than assistants. If untrained assistants, or those who are new to the field, want to use a keyseater machine, and particularly a used keyseater, it is necessary that they undertake training. This is particularly important for work safety and quality assurance. Monitoring the produced dimensions is just as important during series production of components, as it is on other cutting machines. The cutting blades wear out continuously, which leads to the tolerances not being met. Internal groves are mainly used for constructive and dynamic components. Faulty tolerances can be visible in the construction because the built-in components can jam when the machine heats up. These can then only be dismantled if destructed. If the customer discovers the incorrect dimensions for the specified tolerances, then the manufacturer of the components could receive high recourse claims. Therefore, it is important to continually monitor the quality. Since the blades wear out relatively continuously, regular spot tests are enough to notice if the tolerances no longer fit in time. The keyseating process usually ends up forming burrs along its output points. These are very sharp and pose a high risk of injury and damage. Therefore, it is usually required to have a deburring stage during the keyseating process. Usually a standard drilling machine with a grinding head or a hand-held grinding machine is enough. This work is typically undertaken by trained assistants.

Just like all cutting machines, keyseaters produce a large amount of waste. This needs to be continuously removed and properly disposed of. The chippings are very sharp, and should only be handled when wearing gloves. If cooling lubricants are used, it is necessary to clean the produced component. If there is no cleaning station, this task can be undertaken by assistants.

The efficiency of a keyseating machine

The keyseating process is slower than turning or milling work. This is due to the linear movement of the cutting knife, which can only be used on one side. The upward movement of the keyseating machine always occurs on an idle stroke. This reduces the speed of the keyseater machine by another factor. Large keyseating machines reach speeds of up to 20-48m/min. However, this is not comparable to the high speeds of lathes and milling machines. The main advantages of these machines are that they can work independently and do not require much space. Therefore, they are suited to use the available space as efficiently as possible during mechanical production. If a company uses a high number of components with internal grooves, it is a very useful option to use several keyseating machines.

What is an End Finishing Machine? 

An end finishing machine is one which is used for finishing ends of bars and tubes with various levels of sophistication and automation. There are machines available in the market which have the capability to finish more than 1500 ends per hour. Simultaneous inside-outside deburring, chamfering and facing are possible in end finishing machines. 

Types of End Finishing Machines 

End finishing machines are classified into two types based on their application as: Bar end finishing machine and Tube end finishing machine. In the case of tube end finishing machines, the operator slides the tube into the machine collet, and if necessary locks it down and advances a lever to bring the cutter in contact with the tube ends. Some machines are bench top, some are standalone devices while some need a small platform under them to allow proper height for the operator to work on. Bar end finishing machines usually work the same way as tube finishing machines. Some may lack clamp-down and precision sizing capabilities. These machines can also be constructed with stiff brushes instead of cutters to perform the deburring and edge rounding which can be used to remove saw cut burrs. 

Working with an End Finishing Machine 

The operator of the end finishing machine places the work piece through the self-centering chuck against an adjustable stop and pulls the starting lever. This action closes the chuck, pivots the stop clear and feeds the work to the rotating cutters. One of the cutter scrapes the outside edge, one cutter scrapes the inner edge and one more cutter scrapes against the flat end to remove any burrs caused by the other rotating cutters. On some of the end finishing machines, the rotating cutter is mounted on the same spindle as an abrasive cut-off saw. In operation, the work piece is sawn to length and then fed into the cutters. Double end machines are also widely available to deburr, chamfer and face both ends of the tubes, rods or pipes at rates of about 2000 work pieces (4000 ends) per hour. Some machines are integrated into transfer lines using magazine, cradle loading, unloading and storage devices.

Heat treatment is an important step in the final fabrication of many engineering products. It plays a pivotal role in manufacturing where a superior blend of material properties is required. Heat treatment process can be defined as an operation or combination of operations involving heating at a definite temperature, soaking for a particular period of time and cooling at some specified rate. The primary objective of heat treatment is to increase the service life of a product by altering its mechanical properties like strength, ductility, toughness, wear resistance, hardness, etc. and prepare the material for improved manufacturability. The change in the metal properties can be attributed to the phase transformations and the micro structural changes which take place during heat treatment services.

Stages of Heat Treatment

Industrial heat treating operation involves the following three basic stages irrespective of the type of process.

  • Heating - The metal is heated slowly to ensure uniform temperature throughout the surface. If uneven heating occurs, one section of a part can expand faster than another resulting in distortion or cracking. The heating rate depends mainly on the heat conductivity of the material.
  • Soaking - After the metal is heated to a specified temperature, it is held for a particular period of time at that temperature for the desired internal structural changes to take place. The length of time, called as the soaking period depends on the chemical analysis of the part and the weight of the metal treated.
  • Cooling – The metal is cooled to room temperature after soaking period to complete the heat treatment process. To cool the metal, it can be placed in contact with a cooling medium such as air, water, oil etc. The rate of cooling depends on the metal and the properties desired.

Some of the basic heat treatment processes are discussed below.

Annealing

Annealing is the process of heating a metal to a specific temperature, holding it at that temperature for a definite length of time, and then cooling the metal to room temperature. Metals are annealed to relieve internal stresses, soften them and make them more ductile. To produce maximum softness, the metal must be cooled slowly which is ensured by burying the hot part in sand, ashes, or some other substance that does not conduct heat readily or by allowing the furnace and part to cool together called as furnace cooling.

Normalizing

Normalizing is almost similar to annealing except that the metal is cooled using still air at a faster rate after soaking period. Normalizing is less expensive than annealing and also normalized steels are harder and stronger than annealed steels. In fact highest degree of hardness can be achieved by normalizing among the other heat treatment processes. But the primary purpose of normalizing is to remove the internal stresses induced by heat treatment machines, welding, casting, forging, forming, or machining.

Hardening

Hardening is basically the opposite of annealing. A metal is hardened by heating it to a higher temperature, holding the same for a set time and then cooling it suddenly. The rapid cooling is achieved by plunging the material into quench media such as water, oil, brine solution etc. Hence, hardening is also called as quenching as the metal at higher temperature is brought immediately to room temperature by immersing it in cooling medium. It increases the hardness and strength of the material but at the same time it adversely affects the brittleness.

Tempering

Tempering is usually performed after hardening as rapid cooling of the metal results in high amount of internal stresses. Also it reduces the brittleness and increases the ductility of the hardened material.Tempering involves heating of metal to a lower critical temperature (much lower than the hardening temperature) and then cooling at a prescribed rate. Heating temperature majorly influences the hardness of the material, higher the temperature softer the metal. The rate of cooling hardly affects the microstructure of the metal.

Heat Treatment Equipment

The equipment required for the process heat treatment furnaces or other heat treating machines such as induction heat treating equipment, quenching baths or other cooling devices, temperature controls and other indicators required for the proper operation of the equipment or for the control of the process. In addition, heat treating equipment includes tongs and other devices for handling and holding the work while it is being heated or cooled. Equipment designed for the heating of metals includes electric furnaces, fuel-fired furnaces, bath furnaces, and devices for the measurement and control of temperature. Different types of heat treatment devices include oxyacetylene torches, hauck burners, forges and temporary heat treating oven constructed with firebrick and sheet asbestos. Electric furnaces are the most commonly heat treating furnaces and equipment used in the industries.

Threading Machines - Screwing Bolts

As a greater number of screw threads are produced annually than any other machine element there is a constantly steady demand for threading machines and their related accessories, so the threading machine market is a very healthy one. Such items of equipment can be located quite easily and conveniently at used industrial machinery auctions. There are a number of methods  in thread generation, including various means of thread cutting and grinding. The threads of metal fasteners are generally manufactured on a thread rolling machine, and these have a greater tensile strength and are more durable than cut threads. Pipe threading machines have evolved and developed considerably over the years, so that now portable units are available. Such a handy electric threading machine will probably have a cutter, reamer, oil delivery mechanism, a foot operated switch and a stand. Small and compact hand held pipe threading machines for sale are also available, along with a selection of quick change die heads, and are very useful items for plumbers or even householders who prefer to do their own plumbing jobs.

Types of Threading Machines

Common threading machines used for thread machining are the general purpose lathes and NC lathes. Threads are also produced in special purpose lathes and CNC lathes including turning centers. High volume tapping is accomplished using dedicated tapping machines, lathes, machining centers, and numerically controlled drill and tap centers. These drill and tap centers are similar in construction to a regular machining center but smaller in size. They can be programmed to perform hole making and tapping to produce a variety of threaded parts in high quantities. Some machines have multi-spindles and gangs of ten or more taps.

Use of cutting fluids during all thread cutting operations, both internal and external is very important. Cutting fluids maintain lubricity between the cutting or forming tools and the work piece, cool the work area, and flush away chips. But cast iron parts are usually cut dry without any cutting fluid.

Various types of materials are coated with veneer to make them optically higher-quality products. The process of refining wood using veneer is thousands of years old. Findings have shown that the ancient Egyptians (during the time of Tutankhamen) used precious wood boards to refine low grade.

Veneer is mainly used in furniture construction, for window and door frames, and to produce parquet. Veneer made out of high-end wood is characterised through its easy maintenance and robust surface. The most commonly used material for veneer is precious wood, followed by maple, cherry, birch and pine. Precious veneer is made out of teak, mahogany, vavona, black walnut, yew and padouk. This veneer is a particularly high-quality product and expensive. Even though the base material of veneered components are not valuable (sometimes even chipboard is used), veneer is used to transform them into high-end products. With the right level of maintenance, they can last as long as products made out of solid wood. Damaged products that no longer have the aesthetic quality required, e.g. that have peeling or splintered veneer, can be refurbished using reparation veneer. This is particularly the case for edge strips, which can easily repair a damaged surface. These veneer strips are available at all hardware stores and have a thermally active adhesive material on one side. With an iron they can be used to fix damaged shelves, window ledges, or door edges. For these uses and industrial applications, the veneer panels need to be precisely cut. A veneer saw is used for this purpose.

Veneer saws – From a hand-held tool to an industrial machine

The simplest veneer saw is a special hand knife, which a skilled worker can use to produce a single cut in the veneer. How to use this type of knife is part of the training given to become a cabinet maker, carpenter, stair and window maker. There are special veneer saws available in industry to cut veneer for coating series products. These cannot be compared to other saw machines in the woodworking industry. Every component of a veneer saw machine is design to achieve the highest level of precision. Exact stops, precise adjustments and a stable stance during the cutting process are the basic requirements of best veneer saw. The highest quality veneer saws also have CNC-controlled assembly of the entire surface. Using these machines, veneer with gaps, oblong holes, radii and inlays can be mass-produced with a uniform quality.

The structure of a veneer saw

A machine veneer saw is made out of a particularly large work table, a clamping device, a guide and a saw. The work table can easily be over five meters long and three meters wide. The veneer sheet is guided by the stop and cut into the desired dimensions. The clamping device holds the sheet in place during the cutting process. The saw drives along the guide and cuts the veneer sheet into the desired width. Through the turning of the veneer sheet, the thin veneer saw is used to cut the product into the desired width.

Working with a veneer saw

Veneer can be an expensive product, particularly when it has been produced out of high-quality wood. The optimal utilisation of available space is a key requirement when working with a veneer saw. This is achieved by using particularly narrow saw blades, which help to minimise the cut. With intelligent planing, the waste that occurs when processing a veneer sheet can be kept to a minimum. The operator needs to have the necessary awareness of the high-quality materials they are working with, even if the work only requires hanging up the material and starting the cutting process. Taking care when loading, operating and planing the cuts, can significantly increase the efficiency of a veneer saw.

High-end CNC veneer cutting machines contain numerous processing opportunities for the veneer sheets. The programming of these machines are undertaken by specially trained workers.

Accessories for veneer saws

Even though thin veneer saws do not produce as many chippings as milling machines or lathes, these machines are also capable of creating a lot of dirt. Working with a veneer saw requires a daily and thorough clean. The life span of the saw knife can be significantly increased, if it is properly cleaned. With an integrated extraction system, a large amount of the contaminants can be immediately removed. Inaccessible areas are ideally cleaned using a compressed air gun.

The quality of the cut depends on how sharp the saw is. If the saw is beginning wear out, then the operator will be able to hear this. If a dull knife is neglected for too long, then this will negatively impact the precision of the cut. The cutting process then turns into more of a ripping process, which creates an unsightly and irregular contour on the on the cutting edge. This can end up ruining the entire veneer sheet. The veneer saw blade needs to be regularly monitored, replaced and sharpened when necessary.

Waste material often leads to very bulky veneer strips that take up a lot of space. If these are not properly disposed of, it can quickly lead to transportation problems. Special machines have been developed to avoid this problem. The veneer chipper cuts up the veneer strips into small fragments, that can easily fit into a waste container.

Uncoated veneer waste is a natural product, which can still be used. The chipboard industry can use these waste products to produce course chipboard. The pellet industry can create high-quality pellets, which are used in pellet ovens. Finally, they are a good material to use in normal incinerators for energy recovery. Responsibly disposing of waste material can significantly reduce the disposal costs of a facility.

Veneer Processing Machines

Veneer is peeled from solid wood. The first step of veneer production is to use a wood saw to saw the logs into equally-dimensioned pieces. After they have been sawn, the bark is taken off of the logs by a special type of lathe.

Removing the bark is the last step of the peeling process. Special veneer peeling machines which are one of those woodworking machinery which uses long blades to separate the veneer sheets from a rotating wooden log. With hydraulically or electrically powered feeds, the peeling blade produces the required power to cut veneer sheets into equal thickness and quality. After it is peeled, the veneer ribbon is cut. The veneer is then dried, after which it is ready for further processing. The veneer is then made ready for use and transformed into a machine-processable shape, after which it can be applied.

The veneer sheet is applied to laminar components by using a veneer press. The base material is first coated with glue and then, by using a high level of pressure, the veneer sheet is tightly pressed upon it. This ensures that there is a permanent bond. The edges of components, that will be veneered, pose a great challenge. Edge banding machines are used to prepare straight and right-angled edges on furniture panels, and apply the veneer strips to them. Soft forming machines also have the same function but they use soft pressure rollers. These fit unusually shaped edges and can even glue veneer strips to round corners. 

Working of A Veneer Processing Machines

The waste that occurs from producing and processing veneer is transformed into manageable sizes using a veneer chipper. Veneer strips usually have the characteristic, that they are available on a slight diagonal in relation to their length; they are relatively unwieldy along their width. If the waste material from veneer production and processing is not cut up using the veneer chipper, then it would quickly clog up the bins, making disposal costs unnecessarily high. Veneer chippers are simple, robust and easy-to-use machines, which are only used to break-up veneer sheets. Working with a veneer processing machine is easy as it is processed and produced automatically. Workers are mainly required for monitoring, loading and maintenance.

Veneer processing machines have many sharp knives, heavy, rotating machines components and high temperatures. The sheets produced from veneer processing machines themselves have very sharp edges and can lead to injury. Therefore, producing veneer is a dangerous line of work, where only workers who have been trained should be allowed to work. Veneer sheets in their rawest form are very robust. Due to their calculated cut, they are also not so sensitive to shocks. In their processed state, veneered workpieces are extremely sensitive. This is because once veneer has been applied to a product it can hardly be repaired. Scratches, dents and cuts in the veneer usually end up ruining the entire component. Therefore, a finished product always has to be handled with extreme care. Automated solutions are recommended for carefully handling finished products.

Turning stations and industrial robots are ideal for palletizing furniture panels. First of all, the size and weight of the processed panels are insignificant. But robots can be used to ease the work of the operator, and prevent work-related injuries. Also, turning stations and industrial robots of veneer processing machines ensure uniform precision. The handling stages of these auxiliary machines can be designed to be particularly complex. Finally, vacuum lifters or rubber gripping arms are used to transport veneered panels.

What is a Veneer Glueing Machine? 

The machine that is used to glue veneers together using adhesives is known as veneer glueing machine. These machines are widely used in all different types of plywood (panel), ply, block board & woodwork to spread the glue uniformly on the core veneer & face veneer. These machines ensures accurate and firm bonding of veneer edges with no visible joint line. Veneer glueing machines are equipped with the integrated glueing system inside. These machines are particularly suitable for the furniture industry and in making high end decorative plywood. After the well-cut veneers are aligned evenly by the synchronized in-feed rollers, the veneers are directly conveyed to the singular glueing unit for glueing edges and then transported to the heating section for glue curing. The veneer glueing and splicing processes can be accomplished within one single machine. Coupled with double knife veneer guillotines, a perfect veneer cutting and splicing work can also be achieved. Using these machines some of the problems of hand veneering with hot hide glue and other issues associated with pressing veneered work can be surpassed with ease. Veneer presses come in a variety of shapes and sizes and are to be carefully chosen depending upon the requirements. 

Working with a Veneer Glueing Machine 

The veneer glueing units are designed in such a way that they are capable of providing a precise and reliable veneer edges glueing output. Unlike in traditional hand glueing methods, the veneer package is placed vertically with pneumatic pressing mechanism from the two sides to avoid excessive or uneven glue applied onto veneer edges. This allows operators to have precise and even glue applied resulting in a seamless and clean jointing outcome. Coupled with veneers both cross-feed and longitudinal splicers, a perfect veneer splicing work can be achieved. The veneer trimming unit, is designed for providing a 90-degree jointing angle on the jointing face of veneer edges for the strongest bonding output. It follows the similar principle as glue applicator, the veneer package is placed vertically with pneumatic pressing mechanism from two sides followed by trimming. The trimming mechanism can be mounted together with the glue applicator resulting in a combination of glueing and trimming work resulting in high quality of splicing. 

Advantages of Veneer Glueing Machines

  • Increased glue utilization 
  • Perfect spreading of the glue 
  • Minimum glue consumption 
  • Prevention of wastages 
  • recise sticking of Veneers

What is Veneer Peeling and Cutting?

Veneer is made basically by peeling a log machine to produce a thin layer of wood. Machines performing this type of functioning are known as Veneer peeling machines. Rotary peeled and sliced veneers are both made by drawing sharp knives through the log cutting thin layers. Rotary peeled veneers are made by cutting in a circular motion from the outside of the log into the centre. Plane sliced veneers are cut length wise from one end of a log to the other end. These machines allow user to make peeling and cutting of veneer strips of given width simultaneously. To improve the performance and operator comfort machines are equipped with hydraulic lift, which allows to determine automatically the optimal rotational axis of the work piece and combine it with the rotational axis of centring shafts.

Types of Veneer Cutting

There are three different methods of cutting veneers sawing, slicing, half round slicing, and rotary peeling. For today peeling is the most common way to produce good quality veneers which are to undergo further processing. Rotary peeling is the most widely used method among the three different types as rotary peeling of veneers using a lathe accounts for nearly 95% of all veneer production. It is predominantly used in the manufacture of structural plywood.

Working of Veneer Peeling Machines

Rotary peeling involves centring the log or bolt onto the lathe chuck. The log is slowly rotated and the knife carriage moved into the log. The knife then converts the bolt into a cylinder. In this process of rounding, various widths and lengths of wood (fishtails) are removed from the log surface. After rounding, the bolt revolves against the knife at a speed of above 420 km/min and spindle speed up to 200 rpm have been used on large lathes. At slower speeds vibration is likely to adversely affect the quality of veneer, producing a rough and corrugated surface. The gears feed the blade towards the bolt as its diameter is reduced, so that veneer is unwinding in a continuous ribbon. During the process of peeling, lathe checks can develop in the underside of the veneer, as the underside is subjected to tension during the peeling process. The side of the veneer in which checks occur is known as the loose side, whereas the other side free of checks is known as the tight side. The setting of the knife and nose bar pressure during peeling is important in reducing the formation of checks, and also in controlling veneer thickness. Each wood species requires certain nose bar pressure to minimise the development of lathe checks, however nose bar pressures are positively related to wood density.

VENEER SHREDDERS

WHAT IS A VENEER SHREDDER?

Veneer is typically a thin decorative covering of fine wood applied to a coarser wood. The machine that is used to shred these veneers are known as veneer shredding machine or typically veneer shredders. These machines are especially designed for chopping and grinding of veneer wood. Moreover, veneer waste resource may come in different shapes and sizes to the finest powder. Throughputs typically range between 300kg/hr. to 15,000kg/hr. depending on the model, material type and application. These machines are good in controlling and changing shredded particle output size.The discharge grate or screen may be fixed at the bottom half of shredder for getting desired output sizes.

TYPES OF VENEER SHREDDERS

Single shaft shredders

Single-shaft shredders come with a rotor (cutting system) which is equipped with special rotor Knifes. These Knives cut the material that is pushed horizontally towards the rotor by a hydraulic ram.Depending on the application, the size of the screen hole can vary. Feeding single-shaft shredders can either be vertical using a hopper or horizontalwith a vibrating chute.

Dual shaft shredders

Two shaft shredders are used for applications that require a broad range of sizes and can be used as final processing or pre-processing prior to grinding or refining. Dual shaft shredders use two cutting shafts to provide finite size reduction for applications that do not require small, precision reductions. High performance blades provide efficient cutting, minimizing multiple passes through the shredder. These shredders can be integrated with pre- and post-shredding separators and grinders or refiners for further processing.

Four shaft shredders

The feeding of four-shaft shredders takes place vertically via the hopper. In contrast to twin-shaft shredders, four-shaft shredders can be equipped with a screen. This leads to a homogenous fraction size. The material is powerfully torn and shredded by the talons of the cuttings discs, then pressed through the cut grooves of the clearing discs and finally discharged through a screen which is mounted underneath the cuttings discs.

SELECTION OF VENEER SHREDDERS

Veneer shredders can be selected based on the following criteria:

Reduction Ratio

The reduction ratio refers to the amount of organic material that will be reduced after going through the machine. The reduction ratio should not be misinterpreted for power.

Number of Blades

A machine will run more efficiently with a high number of blades. Having more blades can also take stress off the engine and increase the longevity of the machine.

Vacuum Attachments

Some shredder models come with a vacuum attachment that can make cleaning up yard waste less time-consuming.

Router Milling Machine

A router milling machine is used to mill soft materials such as wood, plastic and aluminium for engravings, grooves, mouldings, etc. The machine uses a shaped power tool that is directed vertically downwards over the work area and can be rotated and moved horizontally.

The Workings of a Router Milling Machine

With the mill router directed downwards, the operator can move the cutter towards the work piece or adjust for angled milling, while sliding the table to move the work piece. On a CNC milling router, the router moves left and right, and forwards and back on guide rails.

Router Mill Varieties

Standard routers range from the small to the large and can cut various materials, depending on the RPM of the router. A CNC router milling machine performs much the same work as standard models but the operator can control operations via a computer.

Machine Uses

For a CNC router milling machine, the level of control allows for detailed engravings in wood, plastic and aluminium. With standard machines, a skilled operator can carve items such as tinder boxes and engraved pictures.

Out of the production machine and into small containers

Bags, sacks, bottles and blister packs are standard modes of packaging small to mid-sized products. There are a number of specialized machines available to get the products out of the production machine into their packaging. There is possible as well to find used packaging machines to accomplish all the packaging tasks, for that used packaging machinery for sale should be researched.

Bag sealing machines provide the simplest form of packaging. L-sealers, or form fill seal machines, take products and fully-automatically package them. The products are either poured into a sealed sack, or are horizontally placed onto a conveyor belt. Bottles and tetra packs are filled in filling stations and then automatically sealed, labelled and sent for further packaging. Tablets, small components and small electronic devices are blister packed: a transparent plastic component with an opaque back. This can either be made out of cardboard of aluminium. Depending on the use, blister packs are either clamped, stapled or sealed.

Into the carton quickly

Two machines are commonly used to get the products into their appropriate cartons. The carton erecting machine consists of a roll of cardboard and the finished container. These are used to place the products into the cartons either manually or automatically. The carton sealer closes up the cardboard box and automatically glues it. With an integrated or attached labelling machine, the desired information can be placed onto the packaging. A feed system or packing robot moves the filled and packed containers onto the pallets. Carton erectors and sealers are available as manual, semi-automatic or fully-automatic machines, depending on what is needed a used packaging machine could be useful and efficient.

Safe on the pallets

Pallets are generally the final step of packaging. They are used to host cartons, sacks or even loose goods, like machine components. There is a range of packaging machines available to ensure that goods are secure and fixed onto the pallets. The most common materials used are shrink-wrap film and shrink hoods. These are simply placed over the product and then shrunk using a heat source. Bunsen burners used to be used for this purpose, but today there are special shrink guns available, which make this work much more efficient. As the machinery is large and mostly expensive, is recommendable to buy used packaging equipment.

Wrapping machines are used to wrap products onto the pallet. They firmly hold the film in place and wrap the product tightly onto the pallet. Wrapping machines are available in a variety of forms. Stationary wrapping machines have a mast, which holds the film, and a rotating plate. The pallet is placed on the rotating plate and then bound with the film. The machine turns the rotating plate using electric power, and thereby, semi-automatically wraps the film tightly around the product and the pallet. Mobile wrapping machines have a self-driven unit, in which the foil receptor is integrated. Instead of turning the pallet, these robots drive around the pallet and ensure that the products are reliably fixed onto the pallet. Horizontal wrapping machines are used for wrapping series of small components. They drive through a tunnel, within which the wrapping device is built. Horizontal wrapping machines are not suited for palletising.

A feeder machine may be used during the construction or finishing process, in order to deliver individual components one-by-one to the next stage of the manufacturing process. Once packaged, a pallet stacker or container stacker is then used to simply and conveniently move the boxed or packaged items to the delivery container or truck. Both packaging and handling machines minimise, or eliminate, the need for manual labour while helping to ensure that items are processed and finished according to specifications.

Vibratory Feeder

The most common form of feeder is that of the vibrating feeder, or vibrator feeder. Components are fed into a bowl, and are then subjected to vibrations that use the mechanical dimensions and shape of the components to deliver them for the next stage in the manufacturing process. Typically, this means that a conveyor chute is used that is designed for the specific shape of the component, and as they are vibrated into position, they will naturally turn and basically bounce into the proper alignment. The vibratory feeders chute then feed the components into another piece of manufacturing machinery, ensuring no manual sorting is required while also ensuring that the pieces are delivered where required and in the position that they are needed.

Screw Feeder

A screw feeder is used where the flow rate of the component being delivered needs to be closely managed and maintained at a uniform rate. Single screw feeders can be used for basic applications, but those with multiple sets of screws, which may or may not be cambered or tapered, can give greater control especially where the clumping of components may become an issue.

Component Handling

The components that are sorted during this process may be sent to an additional manufacturing process, or feeders can be used to sort the components into boxes, cartons, and packets ready for finishing and delivery. Once all of the components are packaged, stackers are usually used to move the container from the end of the manufacturing line to a storage area, or directly into containers ready to be shipped.

Manual Stacker Machine

A manual stacker requires that the operator walk with the machine, but stacker machine will collect the boxes or cartons, and take the load before the operator delivers them to the required area. This type of electric pallet stacker can speed up the finishing and packaging process, while reducing load on operators and packers. Cost savings can be realised very quickly, through the purchase of an effective and appropriate stacker for sale.

Alternative Options

For especially large packages, or for placing packaged items into containers with awkward, open-top design, the use of a stacker crane may prove essential. These provide the same benefits as a manual stacker, but they are designed for application and use where access is more difficult. The power stacker is similar in design to a forklift, and is primarily used to move whole pallets. Finished components or items are packaged, and typically moved either mechanically or by human operators onto a pallet, and the power stacker is then used to move the pallet to a more convenient location.

Maximising Manufacturing Returns

Effective component handling and product packaging processes can greatly reduce the overall manufacturing and packaging time required to finish projects. This not only means that factors are able to complete more jobs and work for more clients, but it means that operating costs can be reduced, therefore helping to increase profits and turnaround. Moreover, you have the opportunity, through TradeMachines, to find used vibrating feeders and stackers for sale at lowest prices.

Wood Drying Machinery

Fresh cut wood contains a great deal of water. If the water is not removed, the wood can’t be used to produce a high quality finished product. The equipment that is used for drying wood is termed as wood drying machinery or wood drying equipment. Properly dried wood sells for a higher price and is much easier to work with than wood that hasn’t been dried. When wood is dried right and suitably stocked in wood drying rack afterwards, it machines better, glues better, and finishes better. Drying also improves the strength of the wood, kills infestations, hardens pitch, preserves colour, reduces weight and controls shrinkage. Wood that is not dried under controlled wood drying methods is prone to warping, staining, and other degrade that diminishes its selling price and workability.

Classification of Woods based on Drying

The timbers are classified as follows according to their ease of drying: 

  • Highly refractory woods: These woods are slow and difficult to dry if the final product is to be free from defects, particularly cracks and splits. They require considerable protection and care against rapid drying conditions to obtain best results. 
  • Moderately refractory woods: These timbers show a moderate tendency to crack and split during seasoning. They can be seasoned free from defects under moderately rapid drying conditions. 
  • Non-refractory woods: These woods can be rapidly seasoned to be free from defects even by applying high temperatures in an industrial wood drying kiln.

Working of Wood Drying Machinery

The main aim of a wood dryer is to increase the thermal value of wood. In the process of drying, the removal of moisture out of materials is carried out by means of exhalation and withdrawal of generated streams. All wood dryers are classified, generally by the ways of warmth admission to the surface of the drying materials. There are contact, convection, radiation, sublimation, high-frequency and combined dryers. Convection dryers are more effective for dispersed materials as a desiccative agent has a continuous contact with wood. Depending on the material characteristics and the size of fragments, there are different constructions of the dryers drumming, belt, with a “boiling” layer, aero fountain and others. The speed of drying process depends on the temperature of the wood drying kiln machinery, relevant speed of its moving, specific surface of the drying fragments and physical characteristics of the material. At the beginning of the drying process, the humidity of the material is constant to a larger extent. After a certain period of wood drying time when the concentration of moisture at the material surface goes down as the result of exhalation, the period of falling drying speed and the temperature of the material begins to increase. As moisture content goes down the temperature of the dryable fragments approximates to the temperature of a desiccative agent. Thus, there are some limits for the temperature of the used desiccative agent in connection with the possibility of fine dispersed dry wood fragments ignition.

For an efficient and convenient woodworking unit, a combination woodworking machine combines many tools on one adjustable table.

Overview of Combination Machines for Woodworking

A combination woodworking machine is a unit that combines more than one functional tool or device for woodworking machinery. A common example would be woodworking combination machines that feature a sand belt and tablesaw, allowing the user to seamlessly cut planks of wood and then sand them on the same unit.

The Structure of Combination Woodworking Machines

The design of a wood combination machine is such that the user can easily configure and manipulate the table for different operations, whether rotating a particular section for using the bandsaw or opening a compartment for belt sanding. Power for each functional feature of a unit can come from one source or multiple motors.

Types of Woodworking Combination Machines

These machines combine various tools, and some types will have particular combinations included. A Shopsmith is a wood combination machine predominantly used for shaping wood and, therefore, includes tools such as sanders, tablesaws and drill presses. The European woodworking combination machine will commonly have a mortiser, jointer, shaper and scoring tool for professional applications.
