Why Internal Grinding Machine?

Grinding is a surface finishing operation in which abrasive particles contained in a bonded grinding wheel shape and finish the components made of metal or other materials. Internal diameter or simply ID grinders finish the inside of a previously drilled, reamed, or bored hole, using small grinding wheels at high RPM. Several different internal contours can be produced within a work piece using internal grinding machines, including CNC internal grinding machine or internal cylindrical grinding machine.

Types of Internal Grinding Machines

The internal grinders can be broadly classified into three different types as follows:

  • Chucking type internal grinder – The work piece is usually mounted in a chuck. A magnetic face plate can also be used. A small grinding wheel performs the necessary grinding with its peripheral surface.
  • Planetary internal grinder – When the work piece is of irregular shape and cannot be rotated conveniently, the planetary internal grinder is opted for. In this machine the work piece does not rotate. Instead, the grinding wheel orbits the axis of the hole in the work piece.
  • Centreless internal grinder – An internal centerless grinding machine is used for grinding cylindrical and tapered holes in cylindrical parts like cylindrical liners, various bushings etc. The work piece is rotated between supporting roll, pressure roll and regulating wheel and is ground by the grinding wheel. 

Motion in Internal Grinding Machine

The principle elements of a used internal grinding machine are the workhead, which holds the work piece to be ground with its own drive; and the wheelhead, which is the internal grinding spindle. The most popular internal grinder is similar in operation to a boring operation in a lathe. The work piece is held by a work holding device, usually a chuck or collet, and revolved by a motorized headstock. A separate motor head in the same direction as the work piece revolves the grinding wheel. It can be fed in and out of the work and also adjusted for depth of cut. In addition to the rotary motions of work and wheel, an internal grinder has a traverse movement to bring the wheel to and from the work zone, and a reciprocating spindle movement for both the wheel's approach to the work surface and for the feed movement of the wheel during grinding.

Bench grinder – a standard machine in all operational facilities

A bench grinder consists of a base frame made out of cast steel, a covered electric motor, one or two grinding discs with a protective device, and a support plate. The engine is mounted onto the base frame and drives the central shaft. With smaller bench grinders, the grinding disc is directly attached to the shaft. Bigger bench grinders have a belt drive. The support plate, upon which the workpiece is placed, acts as a guide and is located in front of the grinding disc. The grinding disc is either located on a stable worktable or screwed onto a separate column. It is screwed into the floor, which means that the machine has a very stable stance.

Increase the efficiency: double wheeled bench grinders

Double wheeled bench grinders have two wheels that are powered simultaneously and connected by a rigid shaft. This provides several advantages. First of all, the installation of the grinding disc is left to the operator. In general, course and fine grinding discs can be installed onto one double wheeled bench grinder. Workpieces that are ground can be prepared and then subsequently processed. Turning on the bench grinder uses up the most amount of energy. Once it has been set into rotation, a large amount of the energy required to turn the wheels comes from its own momentum. The braking effect of grinding on one of the rotating grinding wheels is offset on a double wheeled bench grinder by the rotational energy of the two grinding wheels. Therefore, they are particularly energy efficient.

The types of double wheeled bench grinders

A double wheeled bench grinder from Flott

Double wheeled bench grinders are machines used for manually grinding components. They are usually (there is one exception) only suited for large products and work that is not technically demanding. The most common uses for a bench grinder include regrinding chisels, deburring injection-moulded and die cast products, milling flame-cut or cut components, and cleaning tools. Grinders can be required to clean tools if they are, for example, covered with adhesive resin or varnish. Double wheeled bench grinders can also be equipped with polishing discs or brushes, instead of grinding discs. The size of these machines ranges from small table-top bench grinders, with hand-sized grinding discs, up to large double bench grinders, whose grinding discs are up to a meter in diameter.

Bench grinders used for precious stones are the exception in terms of precision. These operate with a much higher rotation speed have an automatic water supply. Grinding precious stones requires a lot of experience and a good eye. With the right skills, the operator of a bench grinder for precious stones can work to a level of precision within a fraction of a millimetre.

Working with a double wheeled bench grinder

In order to properly handle a bench grinder, new workers should receive a safety briefing from an operational expert. It is very important to note, that one should not wear gloves when working with a bench grinder. The problem is that the gloves can get caught by the rotating discs and the momentum would pull the worker's hands towards the disc. This could lead to bad injuries. Close-fitting clothing is required, because loose t-shirts or jumpers could also come into contact with the grinding disc and cause the same problem. The same goes for hair; long-haired workers can only work with a bench grinder when wearing a hair net or another form of protection.

The course side of the grinding disc quickly removes a lot of material from a workpiece. Workers with little experience should practice grinding waste material before processing high-end products and tools. The material that is taken off is mainly caught by the cover. However, there is a still a lot of waste material that flies around uncontrollably. Therefore, it is important to wear eye protection (this is the minimum safety equipment required). Depending on the type of workpiece, sometimes it is also important to wear a mouth guard. Grinding dust from galvanised sheet metal is very toxic. Due to the health risks, it is important to undertake the necessary safety precautions when working with a bench grinder.

Before and during the work, the technical conditions should always be inspected and monitored. The frame, the engine's cover, and the protective cover for the grinding disc could have rips, holes or defects. The electric cable and switches on the control board all have to be undamaged. Before starting the bench grinder, it is recommended to check the state of the entire machine and that the grinding discs are fixed into place.

The bench grinder should run steadily and reliably. During operation, the rotation speed should not oscillate. A damaged engine can be recognised by the development of sparks or turbulent operation. If this occurs, the bench grinder should be immediately switched off and unplugged.

Noisy bench grinders are often the due to the fact that they are unbalanced. This is commonly due to the material only being ground on one side. This cannot be avoided on bench grinders and occurs sooner or later on all grinding discs. The roundness of the grinding disc can be fixed using a straightening tool. This should not be neglected because an imbalance in the grinding disc can quickly lead to damages in the bearings. To repair these would be much more complicated than straightening the grinding disc.

Working with a bench grinder is always very loud. Therefore, ear protection is useful and is usually a requirement.

Cleaning a bench grinder

Because of the abrasion that occurs between the grinding disc and the workpiece, bench grinders produce a lot of grinding dust. Therefore, it is necessary to thoroughly clean the workspace after every work step. Compressed air guns are not suited for this task, because they distribute the debris and fine dust all over the place. Metal dust is particularly dangerous because it is conductive, which means that it can cause damage to electric components or cause short circuits. The ideal cleaning process for bench grinders is just rinsing and vacuuming. Sweeping and manually wiping the grinder with a damp cloth is much better than cleaning the bench grinder with compressed air.

Centerless grinding process is similar to the other centered grinding operations except that there is no spindle involved in the machining process. This allows high through-put since parts can be quickly inserted and removed from the process. The work piece is not mechanically constrained in centreless grinding as the work piece rotates between a high speed grinding wheel and a slower speed regulating drive wheel. The work is supported from below by a fixed work-rest blade and also on its outer diameter by the regulating wheel. As the work piece is supported only by the regulating wheel and the blade, centerless grinding is a more rigid system which provides the advantage of performing more accurate and efficient grinding when compared to grinding between centers.

Infeed & Thru-feed Centerless Grinding

The two basic modes of centerless grinding are "thru-feed" and "in-feed" or "plunge" mode. In the thru-feed mode, the work proceeds in the axial direction through the slowly narrowing gap between the grinding wheel and the regulating wheel. Work is advanced by the axial force exerted on it by the rotating surface of the regulating wheel. This is a highly productive form of grinding in that a number of work pieces can be ground simultaneously and in a continuous stream. The infeed mode is used for work with projecting heads that would prohibit thru-feeding, the work is placed on the work-rest blade while one wheel is retracted and fed to an end stop. The wheel is then brought back, reducing the gap between the wheels, grinding the work. Setting up for infeed grinding is the less complicated of the two methods but for continuous, production type centerless grinding, the thrufeed method is the most effective as often a single pass is sufficient enough to finish the operation.

Application of Centerless Grinding Machines

A centerless grinding machine, or centerless grinder, can be found in many traditional factories which involve high volume production runs. Centerless grinders have been successfully applied to manufacture a variety of parts ranging from hypodermic needles to bowling balls. The principles of the centerless grinding process remain the same regardless of the work piece to be ground. Centreless grinding machines, including CNC centerless grinding machine, have got widespread applications in various industries like auto parts manufacturing, bearing industry, bush and pin manufacturing.

Grinding is a material removal process in which abrasive particles are contained in a bonded grinding wheel that operates at very high surface speeds. Abrasive operations are performed to achieve a surface finish, which cannot be achieved by conventional machining processes. Through the cylindrical grinding process, and by using a cylindrical grinding machine, the external or internal cylindrical surface of a work piece are ground. In external cylindrical grinding machine, the work piece rotates and reciprocates along its axis, although for large and long work parts the grinding wheel reciprocates. In internal cylindrical grinding machine, a small wheel grinds the inside diameter of the part. The work piece is held in a rotating chuck in the headstock and the wheel rotates at very high rotational speed. In this cylindrical grinding operation, the work piece rotates and the grinding wheel reciprocates.

Classification of Cylindrical Grinders

There are three different types of cylindrical grinder as follows:

  • Plain centre type cylindrical grinder - The machine is similar to a centre lathe in many respects. The work piece is held between head stock and tailstock centres. A disc type grinding wheel performs the grinding action with its peripheral surface.

  • Universal cylindrical surface grinder - Universal cylindrical grinder is similar to a plain cylindrical one except that it is more versatile. In addition to small worktable swivel, this cylindrical grinder machine provides large swivel of head stock, wheel head slide and wheel head mount on the wheel head slide which allows grinding of any taper on the work piece.
  • Centerless cylindrical surface grinder – In a centertless cylindrical grinding machine, the work piece is not held between centres but by a work support blade. It is rotated by means of a regulating wheel and ground by the grinding wheel.

Applications of Cylindrical Grinding Machines

Apart from external or internal surface finishing, cylindrical grinders for sale, including CNC cylindrical grinder and hydraulic cylindrical grinding machine, are also used for some special purpose applications. A specially formed single ribbed wheel or a multi ribbed wheel with matching thread profiles can be used for thread grinding. Roll grinding is a specific case of cylindrical grinding wherein large work pieces such as shafts, spindles and rolls are ground. Crankshaft or crank pin grinders also resemble cylindrical grinder but are engaged to grind crank pins which are eccentric from the centre line of the shaft. Cam and camshaft grinders are essentially subsets of cylindrical grinding machine dedicated to finish various profiles on disc cams and cam shafts.

Grinding Tools and Cutters

How a Grinder Sets Up

A smaller implement is the tool post grinder, which can be attached to a lathe tool grinder so that both the work piece and the grinder can be spinning at the same time for finer and more precise workmanship.

Types of Grinding Machines


A lathe tool grinder rotates the work piece allowing the operator to apply various shaping tools such as a tool post grinder, which is in contrast to a tool & cutter grinder where the work piece is stationary. Wood Chipper/ Shredder Mechanism

The wood shredder was invented by Peter Jensen of Germany in the late 19th century. Today they generally consist of a hopper in which the wood is placed, a shredder mechanism and a chute perhaps leading into a collection container for the resultant shredded material.

Often the shredding blades are mounted on a flywheel that is turned by an electric motor or an internal combustion engine mechanism. The shredded material generally consists of chips of wood ranging from 2.5 to 5 cm in size. These can be used as a ground cover or as raw material in the paper making industry. A heavy duty shredder or industrial shredder may be equipped with rollers to facilitate the steady movement of the wood into the shredding blades. It's worth remembering when you're looking for a wood chipper for sale that they come in various types. Most of the wood shredders used by commercial tree maintenance companies employ a steel disc mounted with blades as the shredding mechanism and produce wood chips of a fairly uniform size and shape. An industrial shredder machine may be fitted with a disc measuring 4.1 metres in diameter. Smaller machines, often designed for domestic use, may use low speed grinding rollers to shred the wood. Extraction Systems

Modern exhaust extraction systems typically clean up the gases before releasing them into the environment. Sometimes modifying an exhaust system helps the gases flow more smoothly and boost performance and efficiency.

When an automobile engine runs, it burns gas for power in a process called combustion. When combustion occurs inside the engine, harmful gases are given off as by-products. These gases often leave the engine containing dangerous substances that can't be released unaltered into the surrounding air. For this reason, the gases must travel through an extraction system that removes most of the hazardous substances first. The system also quiets a large amount of the noise from the running engine.

Working with an Extraction System

The primary components of an exhaust system include the exhaust manifold, pipes, catalytic converter, muffler and tailpipe. These components work together to collect and transport the exhaust gases. If something goes wrong with the system, the gases may not flow correctly. This can cause problems with an engine's performance if the gases become trapped and unable to move through the system. Gases leaking out before the dangerous substances are removed may create a possible safety hazard, especially if they enter the passenger compartment of the vehicle.

The exhaust manifold is the first part of an extraction system that gases travel through. The exhaust manifold gathers the gases from the different cylinders of the engine in a single location and combines them in one pipe before they travel on. The gases continue to move through the pipes toward the rear of the vehicle, pushed through continuously as more enter the system.

The hazardous gases are cleaned in the catalytic converter on the way through the exhaust system. The catalytic converter removes harmful substances from the gases, thus making the remaining gas into a relatively harmless mixture that won't harm people or the environment. The next stop is the muffler, which quiets much of the noise from the running engine using sound deadening materials. Finally, the exhaust exits the system through the tailpipe.

Design of an Edge Banding Machine

An edge banding machine is a variation of the veneer press machine, and similarly consists of many components. A base frame and cover houses all of its components. It has an engine for an integrated conveyor belt, upon which the furniture panels are placed. The panel thickness is set using an adjustable bridge. The conveyor belt and rollers, which are positioned above the conveyor belt, are used to press the veneer of PVC material onto the wood panel. Modern machines use belt bands instead of rollers. A veneer press machine or edge banding machine has at least several electrical engines that are synchronised to each other.

Different Uses for the Edge Banding Machine

Edge banding machines are available either as single sided or double sided versions. Single sided machines can only coat one side of the chipboard panel. In order to ensure efficient production, double sided machines have double aggregates, which mean that two edges can be glued and pressed simultaneously. Hot glue is used as the agent for all veneers. This is particularly sensitive towards humidity. Hot glue is applied to the veneer and/or the panel’s surface at the gluing station. Roller systems are implemented for this purpose. The edge band is then transferred from one roller onto the panel’s edge immediately, and then pressed there long enough so the glue cools and hardens. First of all, the edge band is cut by guillotine shears and then trimmed with a precise trimming device. Modern edgebander machines combine the gluing process with profiling the edges. This is and impotent aspect when looking for an edge banding machine for sale.  

A flush and form milling machine is used to create the desired planes, inclinations and radii on the profile of the wood panel’s edges. Because the milling process always ends up resulting in a large amount of dust and chippings (especially with wood workpieces), a powerful extraction unit is important for flush and form milling. Veneer and PVC bands require very flat surfaces, similar to lacquered surfaces. Irregularities cannot be concealed by adding small adhesive layers. Therefore, thin coatings (e.g. for plastic edges) are usually processed using a profile scraper after milling. The machines used for this undertake small steps to scrape off the layer of the milled profile, resulting in a completely smooth surface. After gluing the edge, a flat scraper is used to remove all the remaining glue and edges.

Other optional available aggregates for an edge banding machine are:

  • A polishing unit, which is a felt wheel used to polish plastic edges so that they become glossy.
  • A sanding unit, which later sands down the edges.
  • A spray system, which prevents the glue and surfaces of getting stuck to one another in unintended places.

Edge banding machines are available in a range from easily adjustable table machines up to machines for large assembly lines. The larger the machine, the more automatic functions it has. For small table machines, the panels must be laid in manually and supported during the gluing process. The small edge banding machines are most suited for individual products, like custom-made furniture, kitchens or boat equipment. They are not suitable for mass production. Small edge banding machines can only host a limited number of extra components. Small machines are cheaper and more flexible, but need to be supported by other machines to undertake special customer requirements. The bigger an edge banding machine is, the more accessories and equipment it can have. Large machines are usually integrated into assembly lines and are suited for processing large numbers of products.

Possible Additions to an Edge Banding Machine

A router is a very useful addition to small and medium-sized edge banding machines. This allows panels to be profiled, and for companies to provide custom-made products. These require a powerful extraction system to get rid of dirt like dust and chippings, and keep them away from the gluing process.

Automatic drilling stations, turning stations and automatic packaging machines are useful for continuous mass production. Large edge banding machines can only undertake their full potential when placed in an integrated production network. It doesn’t make any sense for production processes, when the machines are not working to their full potential due to another machine that is old or the wrong size slowing down the process. Therefore, investing in a high-end and fully equipped edge banding machine has to be well thought through. The high capacity machines can only contribute to the high output of finished products when all other processing points also work to the same speed.

Working with an Edge Banding Machine

How to operate small and medium sized edge banding machines can be learned quickly, but it requires a lot of practice. Even assistants without qualified training as a carpenter or furniture designer would not have a problem operating one of these machines. Operating these machines is generally not dangerous. After a thorough briefing and some practice runs, even untrained workers could achieve good results using this machine.

Complete machines do not need very many external operators. The work required by operators is restricted to dealing with jams, cleaning and monitoring the production process. The basic setting adjustments and important job of unblocking jams can also be undertaken by unskilled workers. Production machines always require a qualified machine fitter to set up the machines and to take over if there is a more serious jam.

 

Buying an Edge Banding Machine

Edge banding machines are very sensitive against unsuitable working conditions like changes in temperature, dirt or humidity. They require a lot of maintenance and this should always be well documented. Negligence when undertaking maintenance, especially around the gluing station, can lead to lots of follow-up costs in the future. Surface Planer

This process of surface planing is necessary before wood is to be processed using a thicknesser. The surface planer is a type of milling machine, which removes the material via a rotating knife. Planers typically smooth the wood to make it ready for installation, but they can also help correct any thickness issues. PANHANS 336 surface planner is one model available. It helps with planing trim, and other long boards by giving you a table to work at comfortably. Another option is the SCM F4L model, which offers an industrial machine for planing the surface of wood.

Development of Surface Planing Machines

The first surface planer was made in 1914. Up to this time, there were only hand-operated planers, which required a lot of strength and time. The developed machines saved time and made the work easier, so that more material could be processed in a shorter period of time. The planers available today are similar to the old designs, but those used to be powered with steam engines rather than electrically. The size and weight of the machines are continually being reduced, while more safety features are being added.

Surface Planing Process

The machine mainly consists of a support table, one more or more auxiliary stops, a cutter block with a cutting knife and an extraction system. The support table is used as the feed-in and output table. The workpiece is placed on the support table and guided along the cutter block, which is located in the middle. This part of the table is narrower than the removed component, because the wood will be pushed down by the auxiliary stop, and after the cutting knife has processed it, the workpiece will be flatter. In order to make sure that the wood on the support table doesn't hang down and remains straight, it is important that the table has a height difference. This height difference is determined by the size of material to be removed, and can be adjusted on the machine using a hand-wheel or switch.

On planers, the projection of the knife shaft over the surrounding cutter block is not allowed to be more than 1.1 mm. In order to ensure that the material doesn't slip during this process, the wood is pushed onto the table via the auxiliary stop on the machine. The workpiece is pushed towards the cutterblock either by hand, or the machine, at a speed of about 5-30 m/min. The cutting knife is located on the cutter block, which rotates and removes the uneven layer of wood workpiece, and moves the chips towards the extraction system. In order to protect against flying chips, or accidentally gripping the cutting knife, it is important to ensure that there is a cover. There are three different types of protective covers: clapper guard (attached by hinges); swing guard (swings to the side if there is a risk); and overhead guard (this most modern variation and permanently covers the cutterblock). The planed wood is then delivered over the support table. Normally, an orthogonally facing surface is processed along with another surface that is perpendicular to it, so that both surfaces are at a right angle to one another and run in a straight direction along both stops. After the wood has been planed several times, it can be further processed using a thicknesser.

Advantage of Surface Planers

These machines have a lot of advantages over conventional surface planers. For example, working with a machine is much easier. In the past, trainees used to have to learn planing by hand and memorise the movements. This, combined with experience, was the only way to ensure good results. Nowadays, workers only require a simple safety briefing and a short training of the process. After that, the work steps are all undertaken in the same way. Machines enable exact work, which means that a planed surface has a uniform strength and delivers the same quality. Work accidents with a surface planer can be prevented using the various safety features (emergency stop, cover, cut-off relay). These advantages mean that this is a machine that industry could not do without. The price of the hand-held planer and the surface planing machine cannot be compared. Used surface planing machines cost much less than new ones, and they are able to do the same work. All machines are sold at auction only after they are tested for working condition.

Chain conveyors are material handling conveyor systems used for transporting loads from one place to another. Even though, chain conveyor systems are also used for moving unit loads, they are generally preferred for transferring heavy bulk materials. Chain conveyors are preferred over other types of conveyors when oddly shaped items such as truck frames and racks and conveyor loads with irregular bottoms which cannot be placed comfortably in a roller conveyor are to be transported from one place to another. A chain conveyor is also rugged and more durable and it can be integrated easily with other transfer line systems. They are also capable of even distribution of product loads.

Selection of Conveyor Chains

Conveyor chains can be of any of the following five types: Small pitch conveyor chain, Precision conveyor chain, Top chain, Free flow chain, Large pitch conveyor chain. And they are carefully selected by considering the following factors:

  1. Application conditions: application environment, indoor or outdoor, temperature, existence of foreign objects. 
  2. Conveyed objects: type (unit materials, bulk materials), abrasive, corrosive, temperature (high or low), dimension (for unit material), weight (unit material kg/unit; bulk material kg/m3). 
  3. Maximum conveyance volume (unit materials, kg/conveyor length; bulk materials, tons/hour). 
  4. Length of the conveyor, shaft centre distance, vertical rise, general layout. 
  5. Chain speed (m/min.). 
  6. Number of the chain strands, interval length.
  7. Chain pitch 
  8. Number of sprocket teeth 
  9. Lubrication 
  10. Method of conveyance

Application of Chain Conveyors

Chain conveyors, such as drag chain conveyor, slat chain conveyor, tube chain conveyor, top chain conveyor or overhead chain conveyor, are commonly used in iron & steel industries and mining industries to transport heavy minerals. The manufacturing industry also make use of chain conveyors to carry unit loads, pallets, grid boxes and industrial containers. These conveyors can be single or double chain strand or Caterpillar type chains. Single chain conveyors are generally easy to install and do not pose too much maintenance problems for users. Many industry sectors have installed chain conveyor technology in their production lines. The automotive industry commonly use chain conveyor systems to convey car parts through paint plants. Chain conveyors also have widespread use in the white and brown goods, metal finishing and distribution industries. Chain conveyors are also used in the painting and coating industry, ceramics, thermal treatment of metals, feed and discharge systems of boilers. In automatic painting systems the products are attached to an above head chain conveyor system, keeping products off the floor allowing for higher productivity levels.

The Parts of Woodworking Planers

Whether we are referring to a handheld model or an industrial wood planer, there are several parts that share a commonality. The mouth of the unit is an open slit found on the bottom of the plane. This is where the wood shavings will slide. A depth adjustment knob accommodates for various thicknesses. A knob allows the user to control the planer while in use. A lateral adjustment level ensures that the blade will cut evenly across the entire surface. The planer wood will finally have a handle located at the rear. This allows the user to push the device across the surface of the wood while simultaneously applying downward pressure.

These automated systems may be seen within large facilities such as furniture plants and even timber production centres. One of the most interesting features of any planer is that it can be used for both rough cuts as well as highly detailed finish work.

A thickness planing machine also simply called as a thicknesser is used to smooth rough timber or reduce it to a consistent thickness throughout their length and flat on both surfaces. and it can be considered as the machine equivalent for a hand planer or electric planer, the only difference being it can plane very larger pieces of timber much quicker than the other two planers.

A thickness planer is a versatile machine as it can be easily adjusted to suit different wood thicknesses. A thickness planer is composed of three major elements: a cutter head which contains the cutting knives responsible for the thickness reduction; a set of two rollers which feed the timber into the blades and a table which is adjustable relative to the cutter head to control the resultant thickness of the board. The material removal rates of industrial thickness planers are quite high as they can remove large amount of material in a single pass.

Frame presses, which can also be called glue or multi-purpose presses, are machines that precisely glue angles of timber constructions (e.g. furniture or windows) ergonomically and efficiently together. Where cabinet makers and window builders had to handle screw clamps with difficulty,  presses can now be used instead. The requirements of permanently monitoring the angles, and the uncertainties in the contact points, are not applicable when using a frame press. The space requirement for a press is significantly bigger than that needed for screw clamps. These presses are particularly suited for individual workpieces and small scale series of high-end furniture pieces (i.e. those that are delivered as finished pieces, rather than those that need to be assembled by the customers). They are therefore a standard tool for every furniture and window workshop.

The structure of a frame press

A frame press is most commonly made out of a vertical standing frame with robust and torsion resistant square steel. There is a supplier, which operates with aluminium profiles that can be screwed. These are not comparable to their welded alternatives in terms of the precision of angles and robustness. Adjustable stops are usually attached to the welded frames. The pressing devices are attached opposite the stops. The workpiece is laid into the press and then pushed towards the pressing mechanism using the adjustable stops. These produce the necessary pressure required to force the components together and glue the workpiece. The pressing mechanism can either be operated using a lever, a spindle and screw mechanism, hydraulically ( with c hydraulic frame press )or electrically. Frame presses are always set up so that several workpieces can be glued simultaneously. The working depth of the stops and the press mechanisms is enough to be able to process several smaller workpieces just after one another. This is very advantageous when gluing together drawers. The gluing process and the associated dwell time in the machine can efficiently be used for follow-up work. The nailing in of a cupboard’s rear wall can be undertaken when the frame is still in the press. Another advantage of the frame press is its ability to bend wood panels in a controlled manner. Radii and curves can be precisely produced using these machines. It ensures creative possibilities if operated by an experienced worker.

Types of frame presses

Even though they all look very similar, frame presses differ greatly in terms of their functionality and capacities. Simple and cheap presses are screwed onto a specific point on the floor or wall of a workshop. Mechanical pressing devices are highly capable, but they are not as easy to operate. Hydraulically operated pressing mechanisms are more expensive, but they can also apply more pressure (e.g. two tonnes). High-end types are available with a carriage to be able to move workpieces when required. This prevents fragile intermediary products from having to be transported over long distances. Despite the fact that these machines are generally used for individual production, the market also provides high-end machines for mass production of furniture and windows. Normally, the gluing and pressing of series components made out of complete wooden frames is usually undertaken on angular systems. These require further logistical requirements during operation. An automatic frame press can be used as a useful intermediary step between individual production and mass production. The components of an automatic frame press are much better than a simple frame press: in addition to hydraulic vertical and horizontal pressure cylinders, locking cylinders and servo axes, there are optional medium pressure bars, a lateral pressure device and a triangle pressing device. High-end presses contain a wireless hand panel and an electronic individual control system, so that these machines can be operated by a single worker. The range of manufacturing capabilities of high-end presses is extensive due to features such as automatic loading and unloading, automatic pressing and automatic nailing of floor and rear walls.

Types of Frame Presses
  • A frame press
  • C Frame Press
  • H Frame Press

Working with a frame press

Frame presses facilitate carpentry processes in that they make the monitoring of angles, dimensions and pressures superfluous. However, they cannot be used by laymen. Someone who operates a frame press always has to know what they are doing. Therefore, undertaking training in cabinet making is a useful requirement for working with these machines. If unskilled workers are to be employed, basic briefing (particularly about the functions and uses of the individual components of a frame press) is absolutely necessary. If operated unprofessionally, the large forces that can be applied with a frame press can quickly and permanently damage the workpiece.

Where to buy a frame press ?

Frame press needs to be able to absorb large levels of force. A tensional force of several tonnes means that these machines are very robust. This is particularly the case for quality products from Germany. Because they are commonly available, both as simple mechanical devices and as fully automatic machines, they are often associated with the growth of a company. This means that there is a large supply of high-end, used machines on the market. However, one needs to take care when buying a machine. Unprofessional operation or tipping over, can distort the machine’s frame. Presses with damaged frames can usually not be repaired and should be discarded. Monitoring the angularity of the frame is the minimum level of inspection that should be undertaken before buying a used machine. Frame presses are very bulky, but because they significantly increase the ease of furniture construction, they are very popular in simple facilities and for DIY enthusiasts. However, this does not significantly reduce their availability.

Wood press and its types

A press (also forming press) is a tool used to change the shape of a workpiece while applying pressure. Wood presses are used in the wood processing industry. Unlike presses in metalworking industry, wood presses involve coating and/or bonding wood materials. Wood presses can be categorized into: 

  • Veneering machines - used for processes like veneer cutting or veneer splicing
  • Through-feed presses - used for pressing all glued-wood products 
  • Daylight presses - used for high outputs
  • Press brakes - used for bending sheet and plate material
  • Membrane presses - used for pressing panels, curved materials, laminates etc. 
  • Gluing presses - used for gluing wood or wood-based materials

Long Belt Sander Best in Sanding

The basic construction of this machine is a worktable, a sanding belt and a sanding shoe. The workpeice is placed on the work table, which is generally adjustable both lengthwise and along its width. The sanding paper, which runs over rollers, is pushed onto the material using a sanding shoe. The surface quality is determined through the choice and texture of the sanding material, and the speed of the sanding belt. The pressure of the sanding shoe is adjusted via a lever and plays an important roll in the surface quality of the end product. The other possibility is to press down the sanding belt using a pneumatically-controlled sanding shoe. This ensures a constant pressure and is best used for continuous high surface quality. Modern machines are fully automatic. This includes guiding the workpiece and controlling the pressure and rotation speed of the sanding belt on the material and the area that is to be sanded. For semi-automatic machines, the sanding shoe has to be manually pressed onto the sanding belt and pulled over the length and width of the workpiece. A measuring device or visual examination is used to check when the material has reached its desired surface quality. Once the desired results have been reached, if it is determined that more work needs to be done, then this process needs to be repeated. Very course sanding paper is used for processing metal surfaces. This process is used, for example, to remove welded seams and then to ensure that the surface is uniformly course. Metal has a higher heat resistance than wood, and so the sanding belt machine can be used at a higher speed. Large safety precautions are not needed on these machines because there are no components that pose a high level of risk. However, an emergency switch is installed onto a long belt sander to stop the machine in the case of an emergency.

Working efficiently with a belt sander

There are many possibilities for sanding, polishing or shaping surfaces, and just as many tools and machines available to undertake these processes. Hand tools are not suited for industrial production, because large workpiece surfaces cannot be processed quickly or accurately enough. Long belt sanders are great machines for woodworking and metalworking facilities because the sanding belt and sanding shoe can be quickly and easily replaced. It is also efficient and affordable for industrial production. Because the construction of a belt sander machine is very minimal, there are rarely components that get worn out. However, the sanding belt and beld disc sander need to be regularly replaced in order to achieve the the desired results.

Manufacturers of belt sanders

An edge sander is a belt sanding machine where the idler pulley and drive rollers sit perpendicular to the belt. This is the main characteristic that differentiates it from normal belt sanding machines, where these components are horizontally arranged.

The purpose of an edge sander

Just like normal belt sanding machines, edge sanders are used to chamfer, break and deburr the cut and break points of a workpiece. The vertical arrangement of the sanding unit allows for precise processing. The level of precision can be increased even further by equipping the work table with an adjustable stop. Particularly easy to use edge sanders contain a tilted sanding unit; these high-end machines allow for angled chamfers to be precisely sanded.

Areas of application for an edge sander

Edge sanders are commonly used for manually post-processing wood. Solid wood, plywood, veneer and chipboard are all types of solid wood products that can be processed using an edging sander. The only materials that cannot be processed on a edge sanding machine are pasty and greasy semi-finished materials like rubber or other soft, organic materials. The stickiness of these materials means that the sanding paper quickly looses its effectiveness. Additionally, a paste-like adhesive contaminant would quickly reappear. Generally, metal can be processed on an edge grinder, and particularly soft metals like aluminium or copper are easily processed on belt grinding machines. However, safety precautions should always be taken into account. For example, if breathed in, metals like zinc and lead can lead to health problems.

Uses of a an edge sander

The main strength of this machine lies in sanding panel-shaped components. Floors, side walls, mouldings out of solid wood, beams and frames are best processed on an edge belt sander. The edges can be bevelled in any desired form and the component’s size can be reduced or it can be shortened. Entire components can be fitted onto the edge sander if the sanding belt is wide enough. This is commonly used for drawers and doors, in order to form them into the exact shape required.

The structure of an edge sander

An edge sander is most commonly formed out several components. There is a stable work table, upon which the motor and the sanding unit are built. This consists of an idler pulley and a drive roller. The drive roller is powered by an electric motor. This generally has a 220V power supply. The idler pulley is mounted within an oblong hole. If the sanding belt is switched, the idler pulley is loosened and moved within the oblong hole. If the idler pulley is pushed towards the drive roller, then the sanding belt is loosened to the extent that it can be taken out. There is a variation of the edge sanding machine, which is hand-held. This device is used for permanently installed corners or particularly large components. Instead of a sanding belt, these electric hand-held machines contain an exchangeable slip ring.

Working with an edge sander

Switching the sanding belt requires experience and sensitivity. If the belt is fixed in too tightly, then it could rip. Sanding edges always wears down the sanding belt to some extent, and it can be damaged quickly. If the belt is inserted too loosely, then it can slip through the drive rollers when in operation. This will interrupt the sanding process because the movement of the belt would suddenly stop. Choosing the right sanding belt also requires knowledge and experience. The choice of sanding belts range from extremely course to very fine belts. Course sanding belts are used for stripping and roughing, and to remove excess material. Fine sanding paper is used to polish, round and deburr edges, corners and surfaces. In order to obtain the ideal conditions through adjustment work, it is recommended to use several different grain sizes. The adjustment work should only be done in an area of several millimetres in size. Pieces that can be sawn, planed or milled should be processed with the appropriate tools. Thick workpieces to be sanded create a high level of wear and tear on the sanding belt, as well as posing a fire hazard. Due to the heating up of material, this could lead to discolouration and charring at the point where it is being sanded. After the material has cooled off, these need to be sanded off again. Unnecessary additional costs occur when trying to sand a workpiece evenly over several centimetres. Belt sanders develop a high force, which is directly brought upon the workpiece at a specific point. The workpiece needs to be held tightly, so that it doesn’t jump off the work table and cause injuries. It is particularly important to always keep fingers and other body parts away from the sanding belt. An operating sanding machine is particularly abrasive. If it is unintentionally touched, it could very quickly lead to severe injuries. To make matters worse, injuries resulting from edge belt sanders always have a high infection rate. Therefore, it is recommended to seek medical assistance, after being injured by this machine. High-end edge sanders contain a stop and a guide, and ideally a tool carriage. The workpiece is placed into the carriage and then guided along the sanding belt. Edge sanders for sale are equipped with the necessary tools to ensure safe operation, and to keep the risk of injury to a minimum. Edge sanders are very loud and emit a lot of dust. Therefore, an appropriate hearing and respiratory protection should be worn. An additional extraction unit increases the health & safety aspect of an edge sander for sale. For these machines, this can be easily achieved by using a common industrial vacuum cleaner and a streamlined design for collecting the dust. It is particularly important to ensure that there is no ground dust flying around when processing metals. Metal dust can damage electrical components, causing them to short circuit. The sanding belt itself needs to be well covered. There should be no opportunities to access the belt from outside of the work table’s area. A temperature sensitive safety switch with a bimetal fuse ensures that the machine switches off automatically before it overheats. Finally, the mechanics of a sanding belt’s operation needs to be laid out in such a way, that the sanding belt comes to a halt no more than ten seconds after the electricity is cut off. Working with a sanding machine is generally not so demanding. Briefing and the opportunity to practice on scrap material should be enough to allow assistants to operate an edge sander, and more specifically, to use a used edge sander.

A fladder sander is a more modern method of achieving a clear finish than traditional belt sanders. Traditionally hand held, a fladder offers the opportunity to give a truly tailored sanding experience; it helps finish wood, metal, and other surfaces by deburring, polishing, brushing, and sanding the material. Fladder machines are included in the sanding & polishing machines category.

How Does a Fladder Sander Work?

Unlike a belt sander, where the unit requires a flat surface and the wood or surface to be static, the fladder allows the user to effectively wield the sander in whatever manner is needed. This can mean that smooth shapes can be sanded into the wood, or that wood with inconvenient shaping can be sanded in much the same way as a standard plank. The fladder machine is very simple yet incredibly effective; the fladder and the sanding drum are all that is needed, and the entire setup can be purchased cheaply.

Buying a Fladder Machine

The benefit of a fladder machine is that the drum is the only part that will truly wear down, and this is the piece that is easily replaced, making a second hand purchase a real bargain.

Agricultural Machinery & Farm Equipment

Farm equipment is used not only in agriculture, but also in forestry, fruit & wine production. Agricultural machinery are largely mobile and can either be self-driven or are driven by the universal towing vehicle, the tractor. If part of the machine requires power, this can usually be provided by the tractor as well. A typical agri machinery has to move and process relatively large volumes and masses, and must operational in all circumstances, including adverse weather conditions. Energy efficiency has always been important for the agriculture machines. Classic farm machinery is therefore built to be robust and functional so to acquire used farm equipment could be very efficient.

Buying Used Farm Machinery for Sale at Auctions

Agriculture machinery can be classed as equipment that is used in the operation of a farm or other facility for the cultivation of plants and animals for consumption and other purposes. The period of the Industrial Revolution saw a great leap forward in the speed and efficiency of agriculture equipments used to aid in farming and the increased effectiveness of the processes by which agriculture was effected. The advent of modern steam engines power and the traction engine enabled machinery in the developed world to largely take over the heavy pulling work previously undertaken by oxen, horses and other domesticated animals. The internal combustion engine brought to agriculture a golden era which, to a great extent, we still enjoy today. The basic methodology of such equipment has changed relatively recently since the 20th century. Computer monitoring systems, GPS and programmable controls have all helped to make the operator's work easier, but the designs of farming equipment remain essentially the same, so that you know that when you buy second hand farm machinery you will be investing in agriculture equipments that have been solidly tested the world over and which have stood the test of time.

Used agriculture machinery can be found quickly and easily at auction. Among farm machinery sales, farm equipment auctions allow you to browse a wide selection of farming implements at your convenience and locate a real bargain. However, there can be a bewildering array of used agricultural tools and equipment offered online so that it's very useful to have one comprehensive and well trusted site listing a huge range of items from a plethora of locations.

Development of Agriculture Equipment

An increase in the use of information technology in the agricultural sector and in the farming equipment came about during the last few years before the millennium. It's recommendable to buy used farm equipment as this develops and changes constantly. An example are the tractors and excavators, monitors replaced individual instruments and control systems on farm tractors dashboard, therefore used tractors for sale or used ag machinery are recommendable to search. Standardized data connections allowed intelligent working tools to be controlled from the driver's cab; these were fully integrated into the control system of the towing vehicle. Satellite navigation opened up new ways to optimize work flows in agriculture industry. With a GPS-data logger, the vehicle's parameters like speed, rotation, instantaneous power, fuel economy can be logged and then using the geographical coordinates, can be linked to a load profile. The movements of livestock can also be determined using this method. There are new possibilities to automate keeping livestock, including the implementation of near-field communication in all farming machines. In cattle farming, every animal with the corresponding marking or sensor can be identified using a machine. This method is used to individually administer feed or to open and close gates.

Farm Equipment Types by Applications

The spectrum of the types of farm equipment used is just as wide. In addition to the classifications of stationary, self-driven and farm equipment with external drives, the most important differentiation is the area of application for the many special types of agricultural equipments available in agricultural technology. Despite the universally applicable tractors, single-application machines including straw balers, milking machines or harvesters, are the most prominent. 

Mobile, but not self-driven farm equipment is separated into three groups, depending on the type of towing vehicle. Generally, this vehicle is exclusively used to provide movement. There are numerous types of agricultural and forestry trailers like the plough, harrow, simple hay turning machines, hay sweep, seeding machines, drilling machines and harvesters like the cucumber harvesting machine, which is used to manually harvest low-growing plants like cucumbers or strawberries. The second group are agricultural machines that are not only moved by the tractor, but also powered by it.
Attachments like front loaders, rear stackers, dozer blades and snow ploughs, universal spreaders and solid fertilizer distributors are farm machines that don't only require a towing vehicle for movement, but also the power from the vehicle's built-in mechanics. This also includes straw balers and bale wrappers, bale collectors and bale clamps, manure spreaders and honey wagons for distributing slurry. Machines used to prepare the land like digging machines, stone collectors or tillers belong in this machine category. Planting machines like potato planters, and beet & potato harvesters are also in this category. Mowers and threshers that fall into these categories are commonly replaced by a combined harvester with its own motor.

The third group of farm equipment and machines that rely on externally produced power are those that do not move during operation. This includes, for example, irrigation and slurry pumps to help produce liquid fertilizer, ground drill and pile drivers, chaff cutters, wood splitters, circular saws (for example, the sliding table saw), power generators and blowing machines.
Agriculture machinery has developed into autonomous machines out of accessory equipment in order to increase performance. The combined harvester, and also the beet harvester, are both particularly noteworthy machines. Further types of autonomous farming machinery include smaller machines from stable and stall technology and special machines for fruit and wine between other different agricultural equipment. This includes machines for cellars, wine presses, fruit mills and machines for filtering juice. The agriculture scenario changes with the time and so do the machinery and hence few enterprises and individuals who are interested in testing the efficiency of various machines from different manufacturers and models tend to buy cheap used farm equipment in order to save money and resources on brand new ag machinery instead.

Stationary Farm Equipment

Stationary machines make up a large part of the agricultural technology field as the used equipment do. In addition to universally applicable machines and devices used for stable technology, there is also specialized livestock equipment available within barn and field technology. For example, the systems for taking care of animal's hooves, cattle brushes, stall ventilators, concrete feeders and automatic drinking systems. A positioner is an assisting tool used when working with bulky or heavy workpieces. It is used for manual work and is available in a large range of sizes. A positioner allows for a component to be swung along it's longitudinal axis. High-end positioners are equipped with a multi-axis articulated arm, which ensures a large freedom of movement. Another term used for a positioner is a “manipulator”.

Types of positioners

The term positioner cannot be specifically defined. Basically, a positioner includes every lifting device that is used to suitably position a workpiece so that it can be further processed. This includes lifting devices on presses, metal shears, punches, bending benches and even little machine jacks like those that always keep stacks at reach. Other smaller positioners are simply clamping devices that are used in automobile workshops for engine repairs. The engines are either clamped into these or screwed in, which allows for the engine to be manually turned around so that all areas can be easily reached. Mid-sized positioners are used for electronic technology and switchboard construction. These are work tables where the height can be adjusted and they can be pivoted. These devices are particularly useful for ensuring that the workers can maintain a good posture throughout the working day, especially when working for long periods of time. Most valve positioners are found in heavy-duty industry. With their help, especially large castings and welded constructions can be swung around, enabling them to be further processed. 

Small lifting tables usually have mechanical or manually operated, hydraulic power. Small aids for assembly work in workshops usually have manual mechanics. Mid-sized positioners are available as manual mechanical, pneumatic positioner, electric and hydraulic machines. This includes the turnover positioner and the rotary table. Large positioners are usually only availably as hydraulic machines. Mid-sized positioners have a control system directly on the machine. Large positioners are usually controlled via remote control or a foot pedal. The carrying capacity of large positioners can be several tonnes. 

Positioners can be combined with industrial robots. These devices can be used for loading, processing and receiving workpieces. This is particularly useful when mass producing of complex and massive components.

How positioners are applied

Cast pieces with complex forms usually have deep set cavities and a hollow space where moulding sand collects. The workpiece needs to be completely cleaned before it can be further processed. For producing individual components with different shapes, it is necessary to deliberately fire at all the component's areas that are difficult to reach. A positioner and its optionally connected sandblasters are extremely helpful for this. Complete cast pieces can be ground and deburred using positioners. Complex welded constructions can be built onto a welding positioner piece by piece, without the risk of the welding force not being able to reach certain areas. Positioners can also be used for painting jobs. 

Working with a Positioner

Positioners are very easy devices to use. The positioner is put into a horizontal position via its carrier plate and then guided towards the component by a crane. It can pivot very easily after the component and the positioner are tightly screwed to one another. There is no additional training required to operate a positioner; a basic brief should be enough. Positioners often carry components weighing several tonnes, which can develop a high momentum of force. It is important to work slowly and carefully with a positioner, to ensure that the work is safe. The qualification required for working with a pneumatic valve positioner is determined by the type of of work that will be undertaken. Sand blasting, cleaning and even painting processes that require a positioner can be undertaken by non-skilled workers. However, sand blasting is a very dangerous task and should only be undertaken after receiving a thorough security brief. The hinges of the positioner should be well protected. Blasting is very abrasive and can easily lead to wear and tear. Packing the hinges with plastic foil is usually suitable enough to prevent this from happening. Welding and drilling work on cast iron pieces and constructions should only be undertaken by specialist staff with the help of a weld postioner. 

Positioners are extremely heavy machines. They generally require a separate foundation. Due to the combined weight of the heavy positioner, and the often heavy workpieces, positioners' bearings are under a lot of stress. These bearings are generally set up to have a very long working life. However, it is still advisable to take some care. If the bearings start playing up, squeaking or moving turbulently, it is a sign that they are starting to wear down. If this is not dealt with, then it will become difficult to disassemble the machine and changing the bearings later on. Positioners can move a load in several directions, which means that different levels of force are inflicted upon the device's entire mechanical structure. It is recommended to regularly check the arms for any hair line cracks. This can prevent sudden breakages, which would be dangerous for staff and materials. Ideally, monitoring should be done regularly (in a cycle) and results should be recorded. It is generally recommended that the worker who moves the positioner is the same one that will undertake the further processing work. If the positioner is operated by two workers, then proper communication between the two must take place.

The structure of a raised storage platforms

Not all storage units are optimally used. The more versatile the products are that need to be stored, the more complicated the in-house logistics must be. The workspaces that are required for administration and equipment storage should ideally be located in the same area as the objects that need to be stored. This keeps the transportation routes for loading and unloading raw materials, auxiliary materials, operational materials, intermediary and end products to a minimum. If the required workspaces are not available, raised storage platforms can very easily installed. Modern systems contain a large variety of integrated units. When using components from the same distributor, there are often intelligent, combined systems available made out of storage platforms, shelves, magazines, assembly platforms and office containers.

Storage platforms are quickly mountable systems. With a stable protective support system, simple plug and screw connections, and a large choice of expansion possibilities, they are flexible and can be quickly integrated into all storage systems. Most of the manufacturers use cold-rolled steel profiles, which are particularly robust. There are a variety of materials that are usually used for the platform's floor: cheap and easily replaceable pressed chipboard; decorative and abrasion-resistant plastic panels; non-slip safety mats made out of hard rubber; or galvanised grates. This means that walking on and loading the storage platforms is safe, and they are are designed to suit their intended use. Storage platforms can have their capacity expanded, adjusted and reconstructed. Modern systems are so stable that even production components can be laid on these intermediary levels. However, installing heavy machinery on these systems is not very useful. But they can be very well used for small work stations for manual assembly work. Also alternatively, there are heavylift storage platforms available in the industrial equipment sales for lifting and storage machinery options. They can span up to 12 meters and can host loads of up to 2500kg per square meter. Therefore, storage platforms are the ideal device when it comes to fitting and expanding a facility's capacity.

They can be just as quickly dismantled, as they were installed. The system can be taken apart and reassembled as much as required. If the weight restrictions are not exceeded, then there are usually no components that commonly wear out.

The safety of steel storage platforms

Nowadays, storage platforms are very robust and durable. The standard screw connections that were used before are now commonly replaced by plug-in connections for rapid assembly. This means that the regular monitoring of screws, to check if they are tight enough, no longer needs to be undertaken. However, screws are still used to anchor the storage platforms to the floor. Most manufacturers recommend that these screws are checked yearly with a torque wrench. It is also recommended to put protective caps on the screws. Collisions with lifting trucks, forklifts, or falling components can damage the screw thread. In this case, one could only remove them with force, which usually ends up damaging the component.

The most important component of a storage platform is its feet. These are so delicately designed, that they are easy to transport and assemble, but they still have an amazing carrying capacity. However, transportation vehicles are very susceptible to colliding with them. These vehicles are not very fast, but when they are fully loaded, can be extremely heavy. The momentum of this weight can damage the feet during a collision. Because the feet are joined to the storage platform, the collision then has an impact on the whole construction. If a foot is broken or bent, it is usually not sufficient to just change this component. In this case, the whole storage platform needs to be inspected by an independent expert, to ensure that there are no other consequential damages.

Buying Used Storage Platforms

Storage platforms should be thoroughly examined before use. The damages mentioned above, for example, could turn a seemingly intact storage platform into waste material. In addition to looking for visible damages, it is also recommended to check the corners. Contrary to machines and devices, the older the paint on a storage platform is, the better. Storage systems can be scratched up. Freshly painted units are more aesthetically pleasing but there is also the risk that this paint has been applied to hide damages. Therefore, it is better to buy a storage platform with signs of use, and paint it yourself afterwards, than to buy one that has been freshly painted.

Storage platforms are well suited for the used market. If they have been well maintained, they practically do not lose any of their value. This means: as long as they are not damaged, they can always be resold for the same price that they were bought. Buying used systems is particularly efficient.

Accessories for storage platforms

There is a rich and diverse choice of accessories available and there is a comprehensive range of available solutions: stairs in all sizes; slides; office containers; and lifts or loading stations for forklifts. Additionally, storage platforms can be expanded if they have already been used for a long period of time. All storage platforms have standard dimensions, which means that it is possible to mix and match products from various manufacturers without any problems. The subsequent installation of a sprinkler system and a compressed air device is also unproblematic.

What is an industrial robot?


A robot is defined by the Robotics Institute of America as ‘A reprogrammable multifunctional manipulator designed to move material, parts, tools or specialized devices through variable programmed motions for the performance of a variety of tasks.’
Another way to define industrial robotics are computer-controlled, automation systems that combines the technology of digital computers with a feedback system known as servo control. Industrial robots are provided with sensors which enable it to analyse feedback from its surroundings, and react and adapt to changing conditions.
Industrial robots have revolutionized the industry, and are used in many facets of manufacturing.


Who created the first industrial robot?


The first programmable industrial robot, UNIMATE was developed and patented by George Davol in the year 1954 for the company Unimation.


What are the ‘Laws of Robotics’?


Isaac Asimov initially proposed three Laws of Robotics, and later revised them to four.

  • Law 0: A robot may not injure humanity or through inaction, allow humanity to come to harm.
  • Law 1: A robot may not injure a human being or through inaction, allow a human being to come to harm, unless this would violate the zeroth law of robotics.
  • Law 2: A robot must obey orders given to it by human beings, except where such orders would conflict with the Zeroth or First law.
  • Law 3: A robot must protect its own existence as long as such protection does not conflict with a higher order law.



What are the different parts or components of an industrial robot?

Even the most complex robotic systems can be broken down into a few essential components, which include:

  • Controller - The controller coordinates all the movements of the mechanical system, based on information provided through various sensors. A microprocessor linked to input/output and feedback monitoring devices are the major parts of the controller.
  • Manipulator – The manipulator is the arm of the robot that moves materials, parts, tools or special devices through various motions to provide useful work. The manipulator consists of segments and joints. Joints connect two segments together and allow the robot to have two kinds of motions: linear (straight line) or rotary (circular) movement.
  • End effector - The end effector is the robot’s tool, or ‘hand’. The device is attached to the wrist of the manipulator for the purpose of grasping, lifting, transporting, maneuvering, or performing operations.
  • Power supply - The three basic types of power supplies are electrical, hydraulic and pneumatic. Electricity is the most common source of energy for industrial robots.
  • Programming device - A device used to program or record specific movements into the robot’s memory. Also nicknamed the teach pendant, a teach box or handheld programmer, it teaches a robot what is required to perform a useful task.


How do you classify industrial robots?

Robots can be classified in various ways, depending on their components, configuration, and use. Robot machines are commonly classified based on three types:

  • 1. Types of control system – Non Servo and Servo
  • 2. Type of actuator drive – Electrical actuator, Hydraulic actuator and Pneumatic actuator
  • 3. Shape of the work envelope – Cartesian configuration, Cylindrical configuration, Spherical configuration and Special configuration.





What do Industrial Robots do?


Small robots for sale are predominantly used in a variety of industrial applications which replaces intricate, strenuous or autonomous work previously by humans. The application of handling robots in the manufacturing field can be divided into three categories: Material handling, Processing operations, Assembly and Inspection. The most common applications of robot handling involves loading/unloading of work parts, or transfer of material from one location to another.

Further examples of robotic operations include spot welding, spraying, continuous arc welding, painting, running nuts, heat treating, sorting, parts handling, cleaning, profiling, blasting, and tool changing and measurement.

What are compact systems and how do they function?

Compact systems and compact cells can not be classified under a single type of machine or plant. They are closely connected to what is referred to as cells in automation technology, which also undertake a full process. These generally consist of independent machine tools, which are connected to a common workpiece magazine and are controlled by a central computer. The cooperation of the individual machines within a cell is dependent on the circumstances and special handling systems. A compact system can be a modular unit, but in this case it is still made out of different components that are constructed to work together as a unit. In most cases, compact machines are pre-fabricated, transportable units that act like, and are handled in the same way as, machine tools.

Areas of application: Where are compact systems used?

Compact cells simplify the structure of production machines; they are an independent unit that supply all the necessary features needed for a specific process. They are used in various areas of production: in the form of closed-off robot welding cells for metalworking; bread making machines for producing dough; for the production of BSH, laminated wood or other similar materials; compact systems for recycling production waste; or cells for the complete mechanical pre-cleaning stage for waste water treatment. These applications represent the wide spectrum of areas where compact machines can be used, and they can be found in a great variety of different forms. Their common ground is that they are all used for the automatic operation of production and handling processes. A general requirement for each machine is an integrated measuring and monitoring function for the workpieces and the tools' parameters. In production technology, for example, this includes monitoring the wear and tear of tools, and recognising broken tools or functions for collision control. Due to the large range of areas in which compact cells could be applied, the type and scope of the measuring and control devices differ greatly. For example, for compact systems used for waste water treatment really only need to be able to monitor the water levels.

The advantage of using a compact system is not only the increase in productivity, due to the automatic process. Generally, the integrated controls also lead to a higher product quality. This is also the case when treating waste water, when compact cells are used to filter, compact and drain the solid materials. These processes reduce the plant's disposal costs. Another characteristic of compact cells is that they are all have very different shapes and structures. This is mainly due to the different sizes and textures of the workpeices and materials that they are built to process. For example, a bread roll plant can be constructed in the form of a rollable cupboard, while a compact system for processing finished, large, wood workpieces for house construction cannot be transported all at once. Considering the size of the machine tool and the components of a compact system, the modular construction really offers an advantage. The system can be built step by step, following a certain design, and then expanded into a compact system, where every step enhances the production process and increases productivity.

Who produces compact systems?

They range from small to mid-sized facilities, up to large technology corporations like ABB. Other examples of compact system manufacturers for various industrial sectors are BLUMENBECKER, CLOOS, KUHN, MÜLLER MASCHINEN, SMB and WEINMANN.

Orchard tractors are specialist farm tractors utilized for working in orchards and vineyards. They differ in various ways from standard farming equipment and are specially adapted to suit the environment. A wide range of new and used orchard tractors are available from numerous suppliers.

Background

Some of the earliest tractors to be used in orchards were crawler or continuous track models. They were powerful machines able to climb hills and haul equipment across the fields of California, Florida, and the vineyards of Italy. These machines were modified to protect them from the unique terrain; all working parts were covered and tyres protected from the possibility of punctures from thorny fruit trees.

Main Features

The modern version of this specialized equipment requires agility, power and the flexibility to operate within the most compact spaces, imprtent fetheres when looking at tractors auction. It is generally lower in profile, facilitating movement under canopies. The exterior of the tractor is fully encased to offer protection from tree branches and foliage and the under slung exhaust pipe is fitted with spark arrestors.

Orchard Tractors Today
